26812: Bomb Squad.author: majinara
26812: Bomb Squad.text_parsed:
The card is bad,but it is not as bad as it looks. Some things people forget:
- You can put a counter on a creature in response to the upkeep-trigger of the squad. So that the turn after you play the squad, you can already have two counters on a creature.
- If you have several squads in play, and a creature dies by the counters, each squad will trigger for each creature dying that way
- One bomb squad kills a creature and deals 4 damage every two turns. Two bomb squads can kill one creature each turn and deal 8 damage each turn. Three bombs quads can kill three creatures each turn, dealing 12 damage each turn.
26812: Bomb Squad.text_posted:
The card is bad,but it is not as bad as it looks. Some things people forget:

- If you have several squads in play, and a creature dies by the counters, each squad will trigger for each creature dying that way
- One bomb squad kills a creature and deals 4 damage every two turns. Two bomb squads can kill one creature each turn and deal 8 damage each turn. Three bombs quads can kill three creatures each turn, dealing 12 damage each turn.

26812: Bomb Squad.author: endersblade
26812: Bomb Squad.text_parsed:
I put this in a R/G proliferate deck. Having one or more of these on the field with a contagion clasp, or even better, contagion engine, as well as seedborn muse or some other creature untap ability, gets out of hand rather quickly. I decided to go R/G because of how efficiently green can mana ramp...that, and I LOVE Manamorphose! Drop a Fervor on an earlier turn, and watch the fuse counters fly! I've actually Wild Pair'd a pair of these in once.

Obviously not something you'd run in a competitive/tourney deck. Definitely casual/EDH only. Far too much creature removal, as well as faster agro decks, for this to contend with, without having to run things like whispersilk cloak.

29695: Tireless Tribe.author: TreeTrunkMaster
29695: Tireless Tribe.text_parsed:
Unless you used one mana that could produce W and R you can't win second turn if you play first. You have to discard 5 cards to give it +20.
Playing first:
1: Plains, Tireless Tribes (5 cards left in hand)
2: Draw (6) Mountain (5) discard 4: +0/+16 (1) last card in hand is About Face
Only attacked for 17.
Of course the simple solution is to draw if possible.
Even so that is one risky move, one little direct damage or removal spell and you're left with absolutely nothing! (okay besides land you have out)

29704: Life Burst.author: Angerr
29704: Life Burst.text_parsed: It's true that 12 life for 2 mana can make a big difference, but the other half of the truth is that to get to that level, you already had to spend 2 cards and 2 slots in your deck and thus you are already pretty much behind your opponent in both card quality and card advantage. With the very few exceptions (I can think of Congregate in Urza block which was so much efficient that it was worth playing), pure life gain just is not good in limited play. In constructed though, I remember a type 2 g/w control deck full of wrath and fog effects and life gain which played this card. Poor opponent's creatures...

29704: Life Burst.author: ICEFANG13
29704: Life Burst.text_parsed:
Well in magic you can not lose, and your opponents can win (which causes you to lose) I mean there are a lot of "you win the game" effects, there aren't a lot of cards that stop you from "losing"

Lich's Mirror will stop you from losing, no matter what (I mean for a turn usually)
Platinum Angel, as long as you have it, will protect you from losing.
Angel's Grace protects you from quite a bit of all in's

Those are the only three I can find that stop you from 'losing' for any reason, here are some that protect from loss of life, although with big drawbacks.

Lich's Tomb
Lich
Phyrexian Unlife
Transcendence

Interesting that these effects seem quite white, and the ones with bigger drawbacks are black, pretty cool too

29704: Life Burst.author: DarthParallax
29704: Life Burst.text_parsed:
Life gaining is normally lame, unless it's lifelink, which is repeatable, and pumpable, and in general just plain stupid fast when you think about it. untapping with a Double Strike, Lifelink creature should win you the game if it's power is greater than 2. Seriously.
3 power = 3 damage to them
lifegain you gain 3, total 6 difference swing
doublestrike = they lose 6, you gain 6.
12 difference total. that's over half of a starting lifetotal. And you can swing again if it doesn't get killed. And pump it.

12 + 18 (let's say you giant growthed it) = 30 life in two turns. And you've dealt 30 damage. kill.

compare to just gaining life, and not bringing the opponent directly closer to losing. If you have 40 life and they have 20, there's nothing stopping them from paying 19 into Necropotence and comboing your face dead.

That's why people say 'not losing isn't the same as winning'. Also take as an example, seven cards of mana ramp and 3 turns of tempo, vs. a deck without ramp, but with a mean curve and violent board presence, or a deck with little colored ramp, but a few mana stones to offset a Strip Mine/Wasteland package in a control deck. The deck that is aggressive and proactive will defeat the deck that is defensive and reactive. Control Decks might be the ultimate Kings of Magic, but that's only because they also have proactive, aggressive elements. There is no such thing as a non-interactive deck that wins. There IS such a thing as winning deck where the interaction is one-sided.

29707: Kirtar's Desire.author: Mode
29707: Kirtar's Desire.text_parsed:
I understand when pacifism-like cards read "can't attack or block" instead of "has defender and can't block"

But why don't they use the keyword on this card?
Since the restriction is split up into two parts, "Enchanted creature has defender" wouldn't be a more complicate wording than "Enchanted creature can't attack".
Yet it would interact with cards which make use of this keyword ability.
Then on the other hand, unless you're running cards like Grotag Siege-Runner, you'll most often profit from the fact that the enchanted creature is not considered a defender like on Gelid Shackles.
29707: Kirtar's Desire.text_posted:

29711: Cephalid Broker.author: Ratoly
29711: Cephalid Broker.text_parsed: As Masonthekiller said, IT'S NOT MILL. If it was mill, Narcomoeba would throw a tantrum, and Gaea's Blessing would laugh at you. It's Looting. Get it straight. Looting = Draw X, then Discard X. Mill = put X from top into Grave. Besides, it's only remotely similar to mill if they have no cards. And if they have no cards, you've either already won, or you've already lost. There is no middle ground here, folks. It's not mill.

29711: Cephalid Broker.author: DacenOctavio
29711: Cephalid Broker.text_parsed:
Merfolk Looter/Reckless Scholar/Cephalid Looter/Looter Il-Kor/Riddlesmith are good cards. If you have 3 or more cards in hand, being able to cycle 1 or 2 of them to smooth out your draws each turn is a powerful effect.

Jace, the Mind Sculptor was a powerful card for his ability to "Brainstorm" every turn, but his usefulness doubled with the aid of fetchlands to shuffle away useless cards you just placed on top of your library, otherwise he was basically a fancy Swiss Army Scroll Rack (still a powerful card). All these cards do is give you new cards, guaranteed, no questions asked. They don't provide card advantage, but they do offer card quality, a subtle yet powerful concept.
29711: Cephalid Broker.text_posted:
[autocard]Merfolk Looter[/autocard]/[autocard]Reckless Scholar[/autocard]/[autocard]Cephalid Looter[/autocard]/[autocard]Looter Il-Kor[/autocard]/[autocard]Riddlesmith[/autocard] are good cards. If you have 3 or more cards in hand, being able to cycle 1 or 2 of them to smooth out your draws each turn is a powerful effect. 

[autocard]Jace, the Mind Sculptor[/autocard] was a powerful card for his ability to "[autocard]Brainstorm[/autocard]" every turn, but his usefulness doubled with the aid of fetchlands to shuffle away useless cards you just placed on top of your library, otherwise he was basically a fancy [b]Swiss Army[/b] [autocard]Scroll Rack[/autocard] ([i]still a powerful card[/i]). All these cards do is give you new cards, guaranteed, no questions asked. They [the looters] don't provide card advantage, but they do offer card quality, a subtle yet powerful concept.

29711: Cephalid Broker.author: Aremath
29711: Cephalid Broker.text_parsed:
Card selection is great. Most of the time you're either looking for land or not, and the cards that you draw that aren't what you want are basically dead. This means that on average, drawing a card gives you a 'live draw' 50% of the time. Looters basically give you an extra draw at the expense of a card that would have been dead (a land or something uncastable with current mana) anyways.

This isn't entirely accurate since there are occasions where you either have no cards in hand (at which point it does nothing), or need to sacrifice something important to the discard part.

However, casting something every turn (or at least holding something up) is important, and looking at 3 cards per turn means you're pretty much guaranteed to hit something you want to cast.

29724: Fervent Denial.author: Pinto331
29724: Fervent Denial.text_parsed:
I see this being playable in EDH. 1-for-1 counters and removal are less effective in the format because you have to be in for the long haul, so a counterspell you can drop twice is very valuable. Also to this card's advantage, mana is significantly less of an issue over time. By the end game you could realistically play it and use it's flashback in the same turn.

Also it's a great way to mess with people's heads. If they know you have the mana for it and can see it sitting there they're either going to hold back and not play, or tease you into wasting it. Of course with that 7 mana you have untapped you could drop multiple other counterspells, but they may focus so hard on this they don't consider that. If a card can keep a player from even trying to drop a big game-winning creature, that's useful.
29724: Fervent Denial.text_posted:

29728: Aboshan's Desire.text_parsed:
Aboshon- "Being Emperor of you weird squid-thingies has its fair share of perks... cool pimp staff, daily massages, more mermaidens then you can shake a tentacle at (and I got lots-o-tentacles)... but alas, this Dionysian fantasy wears thin... if only I could have more... "

Cephalid Retainer- "Is there something I can do master?"

Aboshon - "You know, Sometimes I dream about sprouting wings and just flying out of here, leaving all of this behind. I desire to fly high above this tumultuous warfare, wholly unaffected by the nefarious desires of my opponents and my responsibilities as king..."

Cephalid Retainer- "but sir... if you leave we will all surely perish"

Aboshon- "... ...but you're right, the cost for me to reach the threshold of my desire is simply too much... I digress."

Cephalid Retainer- "This odyssey has caused you much torment master, perhaps you should rest.."

Aboshon- "I know now that I cannot rest; not until our oppressors face their judgement.

exeunt.

29732: Zombie Assassin.author: grothesk
29732: Zombie Assassin.text_parsed:
This card absolutely reeks of being zealously over balanced. I would not be surprised to find out this card originally had an activation something along the lines of "tap and sacrifice Zombie Assassin, destroy target creature" and cost a colorless less. But then the balancing hammer came around and hammered him so bad that the card is completely unplayable.

The entire casting cost of Zombie Assassin along with activation is now 4 colorless and a black, remove a creature in play and two creatures in your graveyard from the game to simply destroy a NONBLACK creature. That does not even follow flavor...do the zombies turn to dust? Does it take 3 zombies to take out 1 nonblack creature? Why can't they destroy black creatures?

Bad card.

Zombie tribal, and black in general, has better one drops, notably Festering Goblin and Carnophage. In other words, solid but situational.

29745: Morbid Hunger.author: Sheph
29745: Morbid Hunger.text_parsed:
It is true, this card is very expensive. Take for example a card with the same effect, Essence Drain (one black mana, and 4 cololess). Same effect but 1 colorless cheaper, and only requires 1 black mana. Usually that is how it works with flashbacks though, they add a little to the mana cost.

My point is however, this card is not "worthless", rather it is synergetic. I have this card in a flashback deck, and i can cast it on you..say... 40 times? I only have one but because of it's flashback ability it has advantages other cards don't. Combine it with 3 or 4 catalyst stones and you are looking at 2 to 3 mana 6 life swing.

When rating cards it is important to understand that almost every card has it's place in magic, and it's spot to shine.

29745: Morbid Hunger.author: DarthParallax
29745: Morbid Hunger.text_parsed:
Well, Flashback is honestly a crazy good mechanic. I keep undervaluing it. Snapcaster Mage looks pretty god-awful, unless you know 'Wait. Flashback is a crazy good mechanic.'
Other than that, he's a Flash creature....that I guess you can block with....and he doesn't even have flying? Yeah. He'd be broken even at {U} mana more for how good flashback is, if he had flying.


SO, gentle Gatherers, PLEASE BE considerate to Flashback first.....That Said, it *is* still overcosted even for a Flashback card.....but not for an OLD Flashback card. Remember that Drain Life has been a very popular Win-Con for a long time. To deal 3, gain 3, I would Today pay....probably {3}{B}{B}? On a Flashback card....I'm not sure at all what I would cost the CMC and Flashback cost on a Flashback card of this effect today. Close your mind a little bit to the costs, and this Effect IS worth actually trying to win-con with. And that ISN'T true of a lot of effects. In fact, I think that it's a good testament that, while Power Creep is real and all, it's slow.

This card is BAD, don't get me wrong. It's just not playable anywhere today unless you set some kind of weird restriction like "Use the Legacy Banned List, but all Modern-card framed cards are also illegal, including ones that have been reprinted in the Modern-card frame."

WOW. Actually I'd be REALLY interested in playing that format. LoL, pretty much it is honestly "Junk: the Gathering", since all the good cards that aren't Reserved will get Reprinted, and all the good stuff that's not Reserved is already Banned probably. :P Not even Nicol Bolas is legal in that format XD

Still, there are a lot of cards I don't even WANT to be good. A lot of cards whose effects they have NOT gone back to and made better versions of. Life Draining is not one of those and never will be one of those and there always be a way to Frankenstein Together a "Build a Better Morbid Hunger". In fact Tendrils of Agony shows that this card in the same family of cards that are the Absolute Best in the Game.

29746: Mind Burst.author: OmegaSerris
29746: Mind Burst.text_parsed:
@BiOhyBr
Assumption 1: You draw all four copies in your deck.
Assumption 2: You have nothing better to play (Ha!) on those turns.
Assumption 3: They have NINE cards to discard.

This is more how it would work out:
(You go first and they play one land a turn plus one spell)

Turn 1: 6 Cards (at the end of their turn)
Play first copy on your turn: 5 Cards (1 Hit)
Turn 2: 4 Cards
Play second copy: 2 Cards (2 Hits)
Turn 3: 1 Card
Play third copy: 0 Cards (1 Hit)

Even given the prospect of a GOD hand, you only net 4 cards with 3 copies, that's sub-par for discard cards, especially ones that don't let you pick the card (Duress, etc...). And that makes the last copy a dead card as 1) they play their top card as to not discard it or 2) it is a crappy card they can't/don't want to play at the time so... yeah.

29749: Patriarch's Desire.author: GrimjawxRULES
29749: Patriarch's Desire.text_parsed:
Think of the art as representing Cabal Patriarch as wanting someone to become really, really ill, representing the up to -4 toughness from the enchantment. But why would the creature then get +4 power? I'm glad you asked! The disease is really contagious, so whatever comes into contact with enchanted creature ends up catching some of it, taking more damage than it normally would (because the disease is really serious). This is especially true if the illness has reached its "final stage" (threshold).

The card is also kind of in tune with the Patriarch himself, as he likes dealing out -2/-2 to things. In the end you can always enchant the Patriarch himself with his Desire, in which case he becomes a wandering biological weapon, dealing a whopping 9 damage in case he gets to hit the opponent. Sure, small blockers can stand in his way, but the Patriarch's own abilities should make short work of such puny obstacles.

Flavorwise, I love this card, but mechanically speaking there's definitely better cards out there.

29751: Halberdier.author: jfre81
29751: Halberdier.text_parsed:
If you can get some sort of protection like Diplomatic Immunity on it, then none too bad at all. I like first strike quite a bit these days, especially with infect around. But for the mana I think I'd rather put out a Blood Knight and use another two mana to buff it up with an aura or something. Other alternatives for red first strikers at <4 CMC would be Blood Ogre (new in M2012), Hell-Bent Raider, Lightning Hounds or even the legendary Jeska, Warrior Adept which is essentially Halberdier with haste and a tap-ping ability a la Prodigal Sorcerer.

Also, Bloodmark Mentor can give all your red creatures first strike, so on the curve you can come up with something much better once you hit turn four.

29753: Pardic Swordsmith.author: Kiro
29753: Pardic Swordsmith.text_parsed:
This was printed along cards with Flashback and Madness. If you crafted your hand carefully, this would be a good discard outlet, similar, though not as powerful, to Wild Mongrel.

If your hand consists of stuff like Fiery Temper, Violent Eruption, Firebolt, Reckless Charge etc., then you'll probably don't mind discarding random cards as much.

In any case, this isn't a 1-star card since it actually has the potential for powerful plays.

3/5 Stars.

29761: Kamahl's Desire.author: Aaron_Forsythe
29761: Kamahl's Desire.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #13, 10/13/10

If I was Kamahl, Pit Fighter--a 6/1 hasty brawler--it would certainly be my desire to have first strike. (I see now, upon pasting this comment into Gatherer, that someone else has already made this joke. Good one, lesserimmortal.)

Seriously, folks, there’s not a ton going on here. The only reasonably interesting factoid I could think of while staring at this card was already covered in a Magic Arcana I wrote 8½ years ago, but that’s long enough ago that I suppose I’ll retell it:

The Odyssey style guide depiction of Kamahl had him with short-cropped reddish hair, so that’s how artist Dave Dorman painted him for this card. But when Kev Walker’s magnificent art for the aforementioned Kamahl, Pit Fighter card came in, he had Kamahl as totally bald, and the creative team all felt that was a much better look for the red protagonist. That meant some nimble Photoshop work had to be done to Mr. Dorman’s piece here to remove all the hair.

Fascinating stuff, what can I tell you.

Wait, it gets better.

The art for Barbarian Lunatic, by Ron Spears, had that barbarian as bald, and suddenly he looked too much like Kamahl. So hair had to be added to that picture.

A true thrill ride.

Okay, the card itself… The “Desires” are a cycle of Auras that get better at threshold. I already talked (on Favorable Destiny) about how it is generally unnecessary to junk up Auras with clauses that make them play differently at different times--because Auras by their nature do that already--and I feel the same here, although to a lesser degree. Three of the cycle played well in limited, where both halves of the cards mattered and threshold meant something. This is not one of those three; this is what I call a “quota-filling card” as it exists merely to prop up the rest of a halfway-decent cycle. A bit of a wasted opportunity, and certainly not a way to make your main character seem like an awesome dude.

R&D has grown to dislike threshold over time; I’ll save that rhetoric for the off chance I stumble upon another card with the mechanic.

29763: Lava Blister.author: Bobth
29763: Lava Blister.text_parsed:
Just used this card on MWS in a deck with Browbeat, Pain's Reward, Dash Hopes, Vexing Devil, Skullscorch, Breaking Point, and others, just for funsies. It was really the star of the deck for me. It's 6 damage for only 2 mana, which is just some of the most efficient burn out there. If someone saves their land twice, they're at 8 health. Think about that. Not sure why this card isn't rated higher.

Playing it in a non-silly burn deck will either get you the most burn for your buck possible, or mess up your opponent's land drops extremely early in the game. I wouldn't play it in a land destruction deck, in case they don't pick that option, but in a burn deck, either one helps you out.

@Channelblaze
No. You don't get to keep this if it's countered. You play this like any other card, the text resolves as a whole if/when it resolves. Why would you get to keep it..?

What makes this good is that you don't discard until resolution. By that point it can't be countered so your opponent doesn't have much time.. let's say..to 6 for 1 you. Keep in mind.. it still can happen if you're not careful.

Fog effects, Time Stop, and various other instant speed effects can ruin your day, but should be somewhat predictable.

Read the card as "if you have just attacked with 3 unblocked creatures, all the cards in your hand are now free lightning bolts".

there are a lot of better ways to build a deck but this is an instant speed overrun for R. That's pretty significant.

29767: Flame Burst.author: Cyberium
29767: Flame Burst.text_parsed:
Flame Burst and Kindle:

In terms of raw damage, Lightning Bolt is far more efficient mana wise. In terms of card advantage though, Kindle shines better late game. In late game when bigger creatures come out, Lightning Bolt by itself may not be able to kill as well. Any creature with more than 3 toughness cannot be one-shot by Lightning Bolt later on, whereas Kindle can kill 4~5 toughness creatures at 1-1 exchange. In late game Kindle also hurts more when targeting your opponent. I think Lightning Bolt still wins out overall but Kindle is certainly a solid card.

29777: Wild Mongrel.author: Mode
29777: Wild Mongrel.text_parsed:
(Incoming Mythic Rare rant)

@TDL: Yeah.
And then Wizards came up Mythic Rares, an in my opinion bad concept that was realized in an even worse way.
Initially intended to mark the very unique rares, and instead brought up staple cards like Lotus Cobra or Mox Opal as (vital) mana accel, Warren Instigator as the new Goblin Lackey in Standard, Walletslayer and Batterskull as superior beaters, the Mirrodin Swords (Sword of X and Y) for your weenies or pretty much any other creature, and Jace 2.0 or various other Planeswalkers that are almost mandatory if you play their colors.

Those are cards for the early and mid-game that are just better than comparable cards just because of their mythic status, which is pretty much the opposite purpose of what rarity is for.
The M11 Titans and Rampaging Baloths are similar because of their mana cost which would on regular rares even be higher or triple-costed.

Where it makes sense to use that rarity are the steel colossuses, Emrakul, and Progenitus; or the cycle of Preators, since these guys are really deserve being mythic - they aren't just special because an orange expansion symbol allowed them to do more than your average rare.
So there are also positive examples of how Mythic Rare status should always be used.
But overall, this rarity just made staple cards more expensive... :/

I'm overly thankful Wizards didn't print any Mythic Rare lands so far though.
(Although if there should one day be a legendary land that produces mana of any color without drawback, that would be one exception i'd grant that rarity status even though it'd probably make the card even more expensive.)

29777: Wild Mongrel.author: Taudisban
29777: Wild Mongrel.text_parsed:
@TheWrathofShane I try to avoid feeding trolls but your comments are always terrible enough to earn response.

So, first, this is a bear. That means it is limited playable, period. Sometimes it is even block constructed playable in fringe strategies. Bears never suck.

Second, this a bear with upside. I'll mention limited again, to point out that bear with upside is first pick worthy. This specific upside also lets it dodge removal, albeit at card parity. Here's the thing: you're going to have lands. After you curve out with this guy (I like to never have more than six mana sources in a deck built around him but apparently you don't put cards in decks that they fit into), every land is his. Then there are situation specific cards, like Doom Blade against black or creature light decks that the Mongrel eats. Even mono green, he'll still find untimely Rampant Growths and mana elves.

Third, when you play without a critical mass of blue, Force of Will is a piece of crap. Without fetch lands and cheap discard/cantrips, Tarmogoyf is a piece of crap. You will never play this guy without Basking Rootwalla, so it doesn't matter how bad he is without it.

29783: Cartographer.author: Mode
29783: Cartographer.text_parsed:
@A3Kitsune: Because townsfolk isn't quite a profession. As longwinded said, this was merely Wizards' first attempt of a creature type for average Joe humans, when there wasn't anything else available.

@longwinded: I'm not sure if this should be a scout. A Kor Cartographer might be wandering around and chart the territory, but this chap is just sitting at home drawing maps.
Then again, the one from Exodus seems to do what the Kor one did, so you do have a point here^^

@omniszron: The art's really pretty, but i'm not sure this would have suited in Zendikar (using subjunctive since retroactively speaking, it never got printed :P)
I don't even know if Wizards ever reprinted a card with the same artwork when it re-appeared in another Cycle and not in a Core Set.
How could there be exactly the same person from a different timeline and a different plane? From a Vorthos point of view, this would ruin the ambience. But now if we had cartographers in both places, there would be nothing wrong about it. I do like this artwork, but i'd want a new artwork for a non-Core Set reprint.

29785: Werebear.author: Laguz
29785: Werebear.text_parsed:
Terrible flavor text - thankfully, those unfunny puns have since gone the way of the dodo - and the card wasn't all that great, either. Sure, you can never go wrong with mana acceleration, but why would you play this over the elves or birds? a 4/4 with no evasion isn't going to do much of anything, especially by the time you get threshold. You can speed it up by playing book burning or something, but it's still as vanilla as ice cream and is just going to get chump blocked and then slaughtered by 5/5s.

All while the birds and elves come into play a turn earlier...

29785: Werebear.author: Ideatog
29785: Werebear.text_parsed:
"Werebear?"

"There bear. There Castle."

"Why are you talking like that?"

"I thought you wanted to!"

This kind of thing is some pretty tough design space. Printing it at 1 mana would make a strictly better Llanowar Elves, which is already really good. Printing it as it was, at two mana, risks losing what makes Llanowar elves so good- early game acceleration. Compare Noble Hierarch, which is usually better than Llanowar Elves, at 1 mana for a 0/1 (Sometimes 1/2).

29785: Werebear.author: Dr.Pingas
29785: Werebear.text_parsed:
@Horsemanship: The flavor text is supposed to be terrible. The concept is fine, although a little out-of-place as the only non-black, green Lycanthrope. And I'd wonder what you'd define as an ability that does make sense; it's a druid that goes into bear-rage when your stuff is dead.

If you take threshold on the symbolic level; an abundance of death, it makes absolute sense that a druid who previously spent his time producing mana and being a hippie would start raging with Giant Growth(a card, don't forget) once the destruction of what he loves and protects reaching a certain limit.
Let's not forget that it's fairly typical in most fantasy games (WoW aside, please) for druids to turn into woodland creatures, such as bears; which are usually depicted as highly spiritual among most old animist cultures.

It would have made more sense if he wasn't a bear until you got the threshold, but, oh well. It's always nice to give your llanawars a break and throw in a man with some late-game Lightning bolt and Pyroclasm protection.

29786: Call of the Herd.author: SAllison87

Oh My God it's a...a... Double Elephant!

This is a card worth playing because of the tempo and card advantage it provides. Turn one Llanowar Elves followed by T2 elephant and T3 2nd elephant is a great early game. The second elephant allows you to not play your drawn card, providing card advantage while still having a 3/3 body on the field.

Better yet is to play something like Blastoderm on turn 3, saving the second elephant for when the deck slows down.

Fatties, spendy land destruction, or whatever; I could see a deck working with an obscene amount of land and that, mostly based on the idea that doing that means you've cleared all those "extra" land cards you stuck in and then some. You'll need some kind of card filtering and such, but I could see this combo working well; especially combined with any other ramps like [autocard]Exploration[/autocard] or [autocard]Gaea's Touch[/autocard]

29789: Rites of Spring.author: Mainstay
29789: Rites of Spring.text_parsed:
Really, there's very little reason *not* to discard your basic lands to this card, especially if you're looking to hit threshold or otherwise take advantage of land in your graveyard. You get them back right away, after all.

But even without any other reason to do it, thinning your deck for the mid to late game when you want to draw spells, not land, is good. Not good enough to run it if you aren't already, but a good enough reason to cast it if you are.

1/1 isn't great, but protection from creatures is insanely relevant for both offense (ie. unblockable; equip/enchant it up and go to town) and defense (ie. non-trampling creatures cry)

I was in the process of drawing up a Concerted Effort deck when I discovered this guy, but now I'm quite tempted to do something with clerics, seeing as I have a 2 mana super-wall to hold down the fort while I get the rest of my creatures out. ^^

29812: Sphere of Grace.author: PatrickWR
29812: Sphere of Grace.text_parsed:
This is actually surprisingly decent in a slower format like EDH if you're in B/W/x. Black leans on plenty of cards like Underworld Dreams, Bloodgift Demon, Graveborn Muse, Phyrexian Arena, etc for card advantage and a little bit of pain. This negates the pain, and it fuels helpful stuff like Sphere of Safety.

So, cautiously 3/5 for Commander.

29813: Sphere of Law.author: DoctorKenneth
29813: Sphere of Law.text_parsed: I think it's fair to assume that you run anything with a colour word in it with Painter's Servant. The spheres aren't bad, but you should probably run Story Circle or Circle of Protection: Whatever in your sideboard instead. I mean, the circles have a constant mana activation, sure, but it's worth it when you're facing down some big green 20/20 trampler and you want more than a couple of points worth of subtraction. Of course, when facing swarms, this seems like the better option. Not so. Go for things like Brigid, Hero of Kinsbaile instead, or Windborn Muse, or splash red for Powerstone Minefield (if you don't plan on attacking for awhile). Then your circles can soak up the excess.

Steam Blast
Cave-In
Volcanic Fallout
And the other cards which have already been mentioned.

29818: Innocent Blood.author: stygimoloch
29818: Innocent Blood.text_parsed: An absolutely brutal card, whose stock has kept on increasing with time. More than once I've been going last in a free-for-all multiplayer game, watched everyone else lay their key early one drops, then on my own turn played a Swamp, turned it sideways, and killed five or six creatures for one mana. That's not actually a great tactical play despite the massive card advantage (you're effectively nullling your own first turn to null everyone else's too, meaning net profit of zero and making yourself the early target into the bargain), but that's just a particularly funny situation. It has many other greater applications too.

29818: Innocent Blood.author: allmighty_abacus
29818: Innocent Blood.text_parsed:
Lately my friends have become rather obsessed with platinum angel, platinum emperion, darksteel forge and darksteel reactor. Basically they are all trying to make decks that set them up so they can't lose, then make their artifacts indestructible, and then wait till they can win with darksteel reactor.

This is by far the most devious response to a third-turn tinker into platinum angel. Especially when you have something like bloodghast or reassembling skeleton out. And it gets even more devious if you have a nether traitor in your graveyard while one of the other two guys mentioned gets sacrificed. That actually happened to me- I had a blood ghast, nether traitor and jinxed idol out. I sacrificed nether traitor to hand off the idol to my opponent, they took 4 from the idol (they a paradox haze to boost their reactor), tinkered into the angel (with no other creatures out) and ended their turn with a stupid grin because they already had the forge out. I untapped, played innocent blood, sacrificed bloodghast, returned nether traitor, then played a land and returned bloodghast! Their expression was priceless!

This card was one of my favorites out of odyssey way back when, and it still among my favorites today. It is just so inexpensive! And it's black, so if you d end sacrificing a creature, it's going to come back. And it can kill those pesky beasties with shroud or pro black or indestructibility- provided nothing else is out.

29826: Dematerialize.author: allmighty_abacus
29826: Dematerialize.text_parsed:
sorcery-speed bounce entirely defeats the purpose of bounce.

Bounce is supposed to be cheap and instant-speed so you can punish opponents that try to cheat demon of death's gate (or similar cards) into play via its alternate cost the instant after that spell resolves. If you're unable to outright counter it, you need to have the option of delaying it for a while so you can drop that third island.

And four mana? Come on. Evacuation only costs one more and is a win condition.

This is unplayable as is. Merely making it an instant would have dramatically increased this cards' viability.

29828: Immobilizing Ink.author: Kenji18
29828: Immobilizing Ink.text_parsed:
Well, it seems people have rated this card a 2.

When you consider this card as blue creature removal, it doesn't seem too effective. If the targeted creature isn't already tapped or if it has vigilance, then this is a dead card. In addition, the creatures controller can pay the penalty to get his creature back into the action. For those reasons, I guess I understand why people would rate this card so poorly.

On the other hand, if you use it on your own creatures as an untap and graveyard filling mechanic, I think it can be abused quite easily. When put on a Llanowar elves or other mana producer, it becomes a free way to dump your hand. Enchant an Archivist to start cycling through your library for . Enchant an Arcanis, the Omnipotent to Sift for .

I'm sure most people would much rather play a Freed from the Real, or, even better, Pemmin's Aura (Freed works better as creature control), but if your deck enjoys having a full graveyard and you don't want to run heavy blue, consider immobilizing ink. Plus, immobilizing ink is probably in a $.10 box in mass amounts at your local card shop.

29839: Stalking Bloodsucker.author: MechaKraken
29839: Stalking Bloodsucker.text_parsed:
One of the best engines to get reanimator rolling. Turn his drawback into a bonus, and include cards like Raise Dead, Unburial Rites, and Reanimate to get some powerful creatures out, and cards like Ghoul Caller's Chant, and Disentomb to keep replenishing your hand.

Also works well with Gravecrawler and another zombie on the field.

29846: Buried Alive.author: heenaheena
29846: Buried Alive.text_parsed:
I've used this for a while with Reya Dawnbringer. It creates a cool combo with corpse connoisseur and hell's caretaker in which I animate the caretaker with reya then, next turn, reya brings back the connoisseur who entombs a creature and then caretaker sacs the connoiseur to animate the entombed creature. I use Empyrial Archangel (goes great with Reya, making me very hard to damage, seeing as even if you kill the Archangel, Reya can bring her back), angel of despair (If she's in my graveyard with hell's caretaker and Reya in play, I can bring her in with Reya and then sac her to the caretaker to bring her back with the caretaker, thus vindicating two permanents) and I'm about to try realm razer to repeatedly exile any lands as a smash with Reya.

... too bad entomb got unbanned and Iona was printed, making all my progress feel obsolete. Oh well, I still have fun with my deck, clunky as it may seem.

29846: Buried Alive.author: Dabok
29846: Buried Alive.text_parsed:
My favorite use of this card is the following :
-
T1 : Swamp, Dark Ritual, Buried Alive (search for Bladewing the Risen, Dragon Tyrant and Anger)
T2 : Mountain, Exhume Bladewing. The Tyrant comes into play too, with Bladewing's ability. Swing for 16 with both.
T3 : Enemy has 4 life left. Bladewing's a 4/4. The rest is up to you.
-
I like this because it combines my inner Johnny (Dragon reanimation combo), my inner Timmy (BIG DRAGON TYRANT!BBQLOLZ!) and my inner Spike (Turn 2 damage is, without a doubt, SUPER EFFECTIVE). All wrapped up in one.

Balthor the Defiled and Duergar Hedge-Mage aren't bad, but the real reason to run this card: you can fetch your Dwarven Blastminers and Dwarven Miners, to get a land-destruction engine going, especially with an effect like Heartstone. I've seen people run Mine Layer too. (Of course, this is casual. Dwarves are way too slow to play competitively.)

For Dwarven beats, Dwarven Patrol is about as good as it's going to get, but 4/2 with penalty for is bleh. Dwarves (if they do anything at all) do red control.

29854: Spark Mage.author: Aquillion
29854: Spark Mage.text_parsed: Karplusan Wolverine is way better. When your 1/1 creatures are getting through unopposed, it's usually because you control the field already and don't need this guy's ability; whereas the wolverine is useful when your opponent has blockers. And more importantly, if your opponent attacks at all you can usually choose to use the wolverine by throwing it away as a chump blocker (which is not at all a bad choice if there's something with 1 toughness for it to kill on the enemy side; you trade off with something else and avoid some damage in the process.)
29854: Spark Mage.text_posted: [autocard]Karplusan Wolverine[/autocard] is way better. 29855: Frenetic Ogre.author: majinara
29855: Frenetic Ogre.text_parsed:
+3/+0 for just one red mana? That's actually quite strong. You could for example discard anger, then you have a 5/3 with haste. Or you discard some Fiery Temper. They cost another red mana to play with madness, but can then take out possible blockers to clear the path, or simply burn more at your opponent. Like, discard two fiery temper while your opponent has no blockers, and you'd deal a total of 14 damage with this guy (he'd have 8 power and the fiery temper would deal another 6).
Or discard anything with unearth, or flashback, or recover, or whatever.

He's not perfect, but there are easily decks where he can do a fine job. Also good for hellbent decks. Or Dark Suspicions and Mindstorm Crown and many others.

29858: Blazing Salvo.author: Ragamander
29858: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
nammertime is right; this card is best used in conjunction with other burn spells, since it's a great way to test the waters on a particular creature. If you're especially sadistic, you can hit the same creature with another Salvo (nothing sucks like choosing to take five to save a creature, then having to decide whether to take another five merely to justify the first five you took). And, of course, if you really need the creature gone, you can just fall back on the good old-fashioned Lightning Bolt.

It also works nicely in decks that attempt to deal massive amounts of damage very quickly as a way to possibly trick opponents into thinking you're trying to control, when you're actually trying to Lava Axe them for a fifth of the normal cost and then beat them over the head with Ball Lightning, Nova Chaser, and Shrapnel Blast.

29858: Blazing Salvo.author: majinara
29858: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
This card is so awful! I mean think about it: what must happen for this card to be good? Your opponent must have a creature in play he doesn't want to lose, that can be killed by this spell, and your opponent must be low on life. Then this is an acceptable creature kill. It's still, in that situation, not better than lightning bolt, because lightning bolt would do exactly the same: kill that creature. Or lightning bolt would kill your opponent.

If your opponent has no creatures in play, or only ones with shroud, protection from red and so on: this card does nothing (because it has no target).
If your opponent has only creatures in play that can't be killed by this card (toughness higher than 3, regeneration, indestructible or whatever): this card does nothing (because your opponent will let you burn the creature for three, which then survives).
If the small creatures your opponent has in play are expendable for him (like 1/1 tokens): congratulations to losing, because you spent a card to kill one lousy weak token!
If your opponent has enough life to spare (such as in teamed games with shared life, or EDH or similiar formats where you start with 40 life, or just got some lifegaining cards such as wurmcoil engine or loxodon warhammer): your opponent can easily spend 5 life to protect his creature: then once again, that spell didn't help you.

This card is horrible! It's one of the worst burn spells in the entire game. And no: I'm not exaggerating. If I'd ever bring that card to even a casual team game, my teammates would start crying. And I'd start crying if my teammate would play this. And if my opponent would play this, I'd lean back and assume this game is won already, if he plays with these cards.

Putting a burn spell in your deck, that can't kill players, and that only makes sense in very specific situations assuming your opponent repeatedly makes the wrong decisions, is no good idea. If you play an opponent who is an idiot, then you will win anyway. If you play an opponent who knows what he is doing, this card is completly worthless.

I'd even play ember shot over this. Because ember shot can kill creatures when I want to, and players when I want to. Of course I'd never play ember shot either, but ember shot is still better than this!

So please stop claiming this card is playable, or even good. You just confuse newer players. This card has no place in any deck. It's at the same level of cards such as wood elemental, obelisk of undoing, rakalite or zephyr spirit. Now that I have written this, time to rate down all comments claiming this card is even remotely playable, and rating up the others, to protect the new players from getting wrong ideas.

I agree with DarthParrallax. The fact that this is being compared to Lightning Bolt should tell us something about it.
Personally i run both. Its great fun. Often the situation goes like this: They have out something threatening. I proceed to cast this on it. Figuring i can follow up with another spell to kill their bomb, they choose to take the five(I have very few creature in my burn deck, so blocking doesn't occur that often, they also typically have little else left, it all got burnt.) I proceed to kill there thing anyway using an x-spell or some other large burn. So net result: I spent two cards, dealt five damage to their face and killed a threat. If they let the creature take the three, i burn it with another smallish spell, like lightning bolt. Next turn, x-spell to the fact. Overall result of this: rather the same.
I find the mind games it causes in my deck very fun.

If they let the creature take the three, i burn it with another smallish spell, like lightning bolt. Next turn, x-spell to the fact. Overall result of this: rather the same.
I find the mind games it causes in my deck very fun.

29858: Blazing Salvo.author: Zuty
29858: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
It can't target a player, so it isn't on the same level as LB, but it does what LB does to a creature better than any other card with the same CMC. Strafe can't hit Red guys or players and is a Sorcery, Sonic Seizure loses you a card which can be good or bad depending on your deck and what you drop, Shard Volley loses you a land (again, could be good or bad), and Chain Lightning is a Sorcery.

This card is all upside: You either deal 3 to a creature or that creature's controller takes 5.

Plus, it can target your own creatures, meaning for R you can take 5 damage. I'm sure some insane person could find a use for that little tidbit.

~Zuty

29858: Blazing Salvo.author: BegleOne
29858: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
There are two kinds of these cards; those that always give the opponent the chance to make the right decision and those that just give the illusion of a right choice.

Fact or Fiction and Browbeat are the latter. Book Burning may or may not be, depending on the deck it's in. This card usually gives the opponent a right choice, unless you have tons of card advantage. If it kills a creature it's not that much of a bargain, but if you want to Lava Axe your opponent and can convince him to let you do it for 1 mana instead of 5, you come out way ahead. Oh, and instant speed.

29858: Blazing Salvo.author: DaveKT
29858: Blazing Salvo.text_parsed:
This card is the means to one of my favorite magic games of all time where I was playing at a get together with a particularly snooty player who had just cast his 2/2 'the game is over now, I'm going to win next turn' card.
So, I casually play a blazing salvo. He takes it.
Keeping a straight face, I play a second blazing salvo. Obviously irked, he still takes it.
I play a third blazing salvo. Clearly unhappy and shaking his head, he says he'll take it.
I, still keeping my poker face, play a fourth blazing salvo. It's at this time he looks like he is going to punch me from across the table and finally lets the creature take it. 4 mana = 15 damage and a dead creature.


Long story short, people are right, this card is NOT that great if you only have one of them and are trying to deal with a threat, but that's not what it is for. You use this card because you have a pretty good idea how the opponent is going to react.

If I blast your creature that you MUST have, I know you are going to take a few 5 damage and that may open it up to death from more direct damage.
If I blast your creature that does not seem necessary, I know I am most likely getting rid of it and can drop some haste down on the battlefield.

When I can guess what you'll do when I play this card, I am king.

29866: Liquid Fire.text_posted:

29866: Liquid Fire.author: robvalue
29866: Liquid Fire.text_parsed: They reworded it because when you distribute damage amongst several targets, you must put at least 1 damage on each target. This stops you putting the whole 5 on either the creature or the player. Since the card was meant to do that, the new text allows this too.
29866: Liquid Fire.text_posted: They reworded it because when you distribute damage amongst several targets, you must put at least 1 damage on each target. This stops you putting the whole 5 on either the creature or the player. Since the card was meant to do that, the new text allows this too.

Your explanation makes more sense, though.

29870: Nantuko Elder.author: Saikuba
29870: Nantuko Elder.text_parsed: This card was meaningless printed, since at the time referred only to generic mana costs and not to colorless mana. If you look before Odyssey, you will notice that lands that tap for colorless will always specify "one colorless mana" in English, rather than as a symbol. Of course, everyone knew what the card meant it the rules were very quickly updated to allow this sort of mana generation.

29880: Beast Attack.author: DoctorKenneth
29880: Beast Attack.text_parsed:
Too expensive? It's a five mana 4/4 with flash. With an identical card built in. You'd prefer a four mana version? Elephant Ambush is what you get for four. And the only way you're making big tokens for less then that is if they're temporary- ie, Giantbaiting.

Look, I know a 5-mana 4/4 creature isn't a great deal anymore without some brilliant ability (See Ravenous Baloth for reference), but putting flash and flashback aside evidently, this is not a creature. It can be twincasted for much less than it can be Cloned. And then it can be Cloned to boot. It can be recurred and mucked with more than a creature spell can, and still gives the enchanting/equipping/pumping benefits of a creature. It helps mono-green escape Remove Souls. Etc, etc. If the triple green mana is bothering you, triple coloured mana didn't stop Cryptic Command from being in five-color decks. Three coloured mana? Versus green's colour fixers and the quality of non-basic lands? It might as well be colourless.

29880: Beast Attack.author: DarthParallax
29880: Beast Attack.text_parsed:
Hello SyntheticDreamer, fancy seeing another dude from the future here on a pre-modern card frame card. :P

I 3-starred your comment because while it was 'true' in a sense, I am a history nut and I want as many cards that are even halfway well designed to be remembered on their merits instead of maligned for their failings. We might as well not even have a Gatherer if we're going to judge the past purely on Power Creep standards.

Oh, and 'obsolete' is actually too strong a word because this does make 2 creatures, and Advent of the Wurm makes only 1 creature and you need 2 colors. The Wurm is good but it's not THAT good. I never understood it, but people very happily played Gut Shot when I thought the math was bad in Standard, and they played other Flashback cards that I thought were overcosted to flashback. This isn't overcosted to flash at all, it'sthe same. That must make it much greater than either of us are giving it credit for.

29893: Sandstone Deadfall.author: allmighty_abacus
29893: Sandstone Deadfall.text_parsed:
Uhhh, seriously? I have to pay mana and sac lands for absurdly conditional removal? No thanks.

This card puts you at a disadvantage the moment you play it. You've already played your land for the turn, and it doesn't produce any mana. at all So you've already basically missed a land drop. And then even if you do use it, you lose three lands. THREE.

I guess this was an idiots' attempt to provide non-blue decks a threshold booster? Even then, given how much you cripple yourself (and you can't even use it if they don't attack with a worthy creature) there doesn't seem to be a reason to make a threshold deck without blue, even if it is just splashed in.

I almost would agree with you all....except that I am sure that someone, somewhere eventually, who's an even worse scourge on Magic than whoever cracked One With Nothing, is going to break this card into a million pieces.

And all that will be see is our dumbfounded faces, and we might here a few pins dropping. Because really, when we get right down to:

This is an artifact. And it interacts with lands. Crucible of Worlds? Academy Ruins?

If this really is as bad as it looks, then I'm just being silly and look stupid. But if I'm right, I get to be the first one that called Sandstone Deadfall.dec taking over Legacy and Vintage.

And the bet money will pay for my Alpha set :)

29897: Steamclaw.author: Flyheight
29897: Steamclaw.text_parsed:
Moratorium Stone is almost always better than this, but this can go in my mono-green EDH alongside night soil.

3.5 stars.

@Mode:

This thing, is colorless, repeating, TARGETING, graveyard removal.

The first ability on relic of progenitus, scrabbling claws, and phyrexian furnace all repeat, but they don't target the threat you want gone.
The second abilities on the phyrexian furnace and the scrabbling claws, target, but you can only use them once.
Relic's second ability hits all graveyards, but you can only use it once.

I'm not saying the others are bad, but they sure as heck aren't necessarily better than the steam claw either. They have different roles.

If I want mass removal, I'll go for the relic, bojuka bog, and/or Tormod's Crypt. If I don't care what gets removed, I'll play the furnace (and the scrabbling claws for redundancy).

29897: Steamclaw.author: ninjaman98
29897: Steamclaw.text_parsed:
The Trauma - Chapter 1
Gatherings

Through the mists, a tower emerged at last.
Finally.
The quest was over.
They had found the Weatherlight.

Tessira, the young elf archer, lead the group like a wolf. Her arms swaying casually as they approoched the tower. Henmir, the Aethermage, hung loosely at the back, while Nemira Sengir, the last of the Sengir Vampire Family, hung in the middle.

"The Utopia Crystal must be here" whispered Merrar, a brave yet scrawney Kithkin, "Just up ahead" said Tessira." The Aethermage did nothing but continue to aimlessly sculpt the same piece of Darksteel over and over.

"We're here!" cried Nemira!

"Stop!" shouted a high-pitched noise through the fog.

"Who's there!" shouted Merrar.

Check in for chapter two here; at the Weatherlight
29897: Steamclaw.text_posted:
[b] The Trauma - Chapter 1[/b]
[u] Gatherings [/u]

Through the mists, a tower emerged at last.
Finally.
The quest was over.
They had found the Weatherlight.

Tessira, the young elf archer, lead the group like a wolf. Her arms swaying casually as they approoched the tower. Henmir, the Aethermage, hung loosely at the back, while Nemira Sengir, the last of the Sengir Vampire Family, hung in the middle.

"The Utopia Crystal must be here" whispered Merrar, a brave yet scrawney Kithkin, "Just up ahead" said Tessira." The Aethermage did nothing but continue to aimlessly sculpt the same piece of Darksteel over and over.

"We're here!" cried Nemira!

29902: Nomad Stadium.author: Psychrates
29902: Nomad Stadium.text_parsed:
I like it. Typically you would Armageddon w/ a Dingus Egg out, sending all lands to the GY taking 2 for each land and subsequently screw yourself. Now, I could cast Reverse Damage, or Circle Of Protection: Artifact or some garbage, right? If it's countered though, S.O.L huh?

Not anymore.
If you're behind on life, and your ultimate goal is to possibly cause all involved a heap o' damage, you lose. Well my friends, that's the biggest PITA about Land Destruction. This card allows me to gain 4 life just before resolution of the Armageddon, thus off-setting the damage of up 2 lands going to my GY.

29906: Barbarian Ring.author: thedarkheathen
29906: Barbarian Ring.text_parsed: I run 3 in my burn deck in legacy. It's helped out pretty often before, since by the time I reach threshold I'll have done 16.6 points of damage, on average, assuming that my opponent hasn't taken damage from a Browbeat or I've managed to kick a Burst Lightning, other things being equal. While it can be instrumental in reaching the mystical 20, it can also be a real hindrance if I've got one or two Fireblast in hand and not enough mountains. Fireblast can actually be useful in reaching threshold, since if your opponent is on 5-6, you can use a Fireblast and then reach threshold so you can deal the final 1-2 with barbarian ring.

It's helped out pretty often before, since by the time I reach threshold I'll have done 16.6 points of damage, on average, assuming that my opponent hasn't taken damage from a [autocard]Browbeat[/autocard] or I've managed to kick a [autocard]Burst Lightning[/autocard], other things being equal. While it can be instrumental in reaching the mystical 20, it can also be a real hindrance if I've got one or two [autocard]Fireblast[/autocard] in hand and not enough mountains. Fireblast can actually be useful in reaching threshold, since if your opponent is on 5-6, you can use a Fireblast and then reach threshold so you can deal the final 1-2 with barbarian ring.

29906: Barbarian Ring.author: Maraxas-of-Keld
29906: Barbarian Ring.text_parsed: My Sligh deck has a high amount of burn and creatures like Mogg Fanatic and Keldon Marauders, so I reach threshold about when I run out of gas, and this helps me finish the job.
29906: Barbarian Ring.text_posted: My Sligh deck has a high amount of burn and creatures like [autocard]Mogg Fanatic[/autocard] and [autocard]Keldon Marauders[/autocard], so I reach threshold about when I run out of gas, and this helps me finish the job.

29906: Barbarian Ring.author: blurrymadness
29906: Barbarian Ring.text_parsed:
@zk3
But zk3, you have that backwards! You silly. Decks that kill fast still use a lot of cards. Imagine any number of kiln fiend combos. They usually hit for 12-28 damage turn3-4 but they cost a card (kiln fiend) and then usually 2-3 buff cards. That right there can be half of threshold!

Keldon Marauders, Spark Elemental, Hellspark Elemental, Ball Lightning, most Burn cards, buffs, sandstone needle (awesome for this kind of thing IMO), all of these go away quickly and are considered fairly efficient and if you kill your opponent, great! But there will still be times that you'll need that last couple damage, or you're getting too many lands, or blah blah, and thus an extra couple shock that also work as lands (that don't come into play tapped mind you) are pretty spiff.

29913: Graceful Antelope.text_parsed:
To save time for those who were about to look it up, the following is an official list of creatures that have the "plainswalk" ability as of the Innistrad block:

Boggart Arsonists
Righteous Avengers
Zodiac Rooster
Old Fogey (from the Unhinged set, so not "official" per se.

One can give all white creatures plainswalk with the enchantment Aysen Highway or you can deny the above four plainswalker creatures their ability with Lord Magnus. Apparently having unblockable creatures against white was too unbalanced in Wizards of the Coast's eyes.

29916: Delaying Shield.author: Artscrafter
29916: Delaying Shield.text_parsed:
Could be useful in executing a win condition with Near-Death Experience, but it'd be painfully obvious that you're trying for it so your opponent will probably wait until they can hit you for more than you can pay off (assuming they don't have enchantment removal.) Probably works best when paired with self-burn at the end of opponent's turn so you can fine-tune the results.

Scars gave this card another fun toy as you can now imprint Vampire Hexmage onto Mimic Vat. This could also function as decent sideboard tech against infect since it turns damage into life loss.

@TheSwarm: Technically, this doesn't prevent damage. The first part of it is a replacement effect (noted by the if/would/instead wording.) So this functions perfectly well in the face of "damage can't be prevented" effects.

29916: Delaying Shield.author: Mode

Not that impressive without a combo, but remember that this will often still do more than just delay things.
It saves you from a mess of triggered abilities, or poison counters through infect.

As mentioned before, it assures a successfull Luminarch Ascension, and removing counters can be done i various ways, or skipping the upkeep right away of course.
Let your Vampire Hexmage purge the shield, flicker it into amnesia (pity this doesn't work with Venser), or just stifle the trigger. Or at least reduce its harm for some good use with Hex Parasite.

Pro Tip: Do not cast this enchantment multiple times :D

@Manji187: If you're looking for a Dismantle combo, forget about this and Liquimetal Coating and use a Sun Droplet right away.

29917: Divine Sacrament.author: Arachobia
29917: Divine Sacrament.text_parsed:
Arachobia's Named Card Comments: Divine

At time of writing, this is the highest ranked 'Divine' card.

To be honest, I don't see why. Glorious Anthem costs the same and only boosts your creatures, regardless of color. Honor of the Pure is a cheaper boost for white creatures.

Sure, it can potentially give an extra +2/+2 instead of +1/+1 life the other two. But if your opponent also is running white, it helps them too. Worse, in putting more stuff in your graveyard, another white player can be gaining card advantage an boosting his own creatures more.

Against non-white decks its certainly tempting to run this instead of Honor or Anthem. But its inclusion in the main deck is debatable. I can see this as a side-deck option if your opponent isn't using white (or you have some way of countering white if they are), to replace your Anthem or Honor. But, then again, that may just be wasting a good side deck option.

I'm not saying this card is awful, it's not bad and can be helpful. But its inclusion in a deck over the alternatives is questionable.

29918: Earnest Fellowship.author: ZaLiTHkA
29918: Earnest Fellowship.text_parsed:
@XTwistedsoulx: I know your comment is already more than a year old and I'm not sure if the rule has perhaps changed since then, but for the sake of other people reading this page now..

A creature with protection from a specific colour (or lack thereof) does not prevent it from being assigned to block an attacking creature of that colour, it only protects it from the damage it would take from an attacking creature that it's assigned to block. As stated in the MTG Rules Wiki:

"Creatures of the stated quality cannot Block the protected creature. So, a creature with protection from artifacts could not be blocked by artifact creatures. This does not prevent the protected creature from blocking those creatures, but they cannot block it. For example, White Knight cannot be blocked by black creatures, but it's still free to block other black creatures when they attack you."

Source: http://mtg.wikia.com/wiki/Protection

But another interesting fact to note is that it also prevents players from buffing there own creatures without using a off color spell. I did this to a friend playing a Black white deck and nullifide his edge of divinitys. Same thing for giant growth and there ilk. Take that collosal might!

All and all I love that card mainly for the amount of head scratching it causes. If you see this dropped across from you, its there for a reason and you need to disenchant, mortify, erase and tranquility it with extreem prejudice. Its getting ready to win a game.

29925: Patron Wizard.author: zk3
29925: Patron Wizard.text_parsed:
Wait until your opponent's turn to slap this onto the battlefield with Aether Vial or Leyline of Anticipation.
Imagine:
T1: Aether Vial
T2: Vial at 1 for Sage of Epityr during your upkeep to Ponder. You've seen 12 cards from your deck - a fifth of your library. Crack a fetchland to shuffle away unwanted cards and cast Information Dealer
T3: Tap Dealer during your upkeep to ponder again; put onto the battlefield something CMC = 2 (with vial) or something CMC=3 hardcast. You can also leave mana open for countermagic. You have seen 15 cards at this point - a quarter of your library.
T4: Wizardcycle Vedalken Aethermage during your upkeep for patron wizard (vial at 3) - this also shuffle's your last turn library manipulation. Tap Dealer during upkeep to ponder again up a Force of Will (in case) or something for T5. You have seen 20 cards at this point. That's an entire third of your library, which should give you whatever you need.
Vial in your Patron whenever for a free Rune Snag and lockdown.

29925: Patron Wizard.author: ICEFANG13
29925: Patron Wizard.text_parsed:
@Bulhakas

I think auriscope was making fun of you.

What you said, is pretty dumb, I know that people may underestimate how hard or easy it is to play a deck, but each color, and each deck has different things that are hard and easy.

My main deck is a Time Spiral Standard Fungus deck. I swarm people, and all my creatures are very cost efficient. Saying that my deck is skill-less means you haven't used it before (you may not think that), it take a lot of thought and focus to spend Saprolings as a smart invesment, I use too many, I die, I use too little, I die.

Annilator 6 is only on Emrakul, the Aeons Torn and he costs 15 FREAKING MANA! Its a skill to get that much mana out, or make a deck that gets it out and kills you with it before you kill it. Make a better deck.

Counter unless you play one? Sounds like he swarmed you with one of the MANY wizard swarming token cards. MAKE A BETTER DECK! He has to keep track of his 'saprolings' too, tap too many, and he's open, tap not enough, and you will overrun his weaker creatures.

Its not even a hard counter. Lodestone Golem must be in the same train of thought, he requires less thought than this card does.

I would love to see your deck list, I'm sure it would be effortless to improve on, or at least your knowledge of the game.

29925: Patron Wizard.author: blurrymadness
29925: Patron Wizard.text_parsed:
Ridiculously good, 5/5. Comes with Force Spike protection at a minimum, as much as a mana leak if you curved out and dodged removal. As with most tribal decks, if you let them get this Lord out before picking on their board presence, you'll have issues coming back.

Recent printings of Supreme Verdict and Abrupt Decay offer easy outs to the right colors; and creatures like Fume Spitter can give you an easy non-spell way to deal with some of his friends. Cards with split second can help you as well, or Grim Lavamancer :)

29931: Cognivore.author: DysprosiumJudas
29931: Cognivore.text_parsed:
Wizards should make a "Greater Cognivore" for the next Core set. Everything would be the same, except it costs XUU, whereas X is the amount of instants in all graveyards. That way you cast Cognivore early on and then watch as he grows stronger and as your opponent becomes hesitant to cast instants. Or, if you're playing Red, wait for a bit and then cast it mid-game once it's out of Flame Slash and Burst Lightning range, and watch your opponent squirm as they come face to face with something that they may very well be unprepared to deal with.

There is so much interestingness lurking in Cognivore that it'd be a shame to let it die with a silly overcosting mistake. Wizards need to redo this card, but redo it right. If they do, I think they have a card that may very well be a strong Standard-shaper on their hands.

29934: Unifying Theory.author: Mode
29934: Unifying Theory.text_parsed:
Having the choice to make any of your spells to cantrips doesn't sound bad, optional card advantage is a good thing.
But i really don't like the idea of allowing my opponents to do the same...
Imagine you play the card and pass, then your opponent pays and draws. At this point both of you paid two mana, yet you're the one left with one card less while your opponent got one card more.

29934: Unifying Theory.author: Ritius
29934: Unifying Theory.text_parsed:
@ Mode,
Only the player who played the spell is able to pay the additional cost to draw a card.

This would be good in a stagnation blue deck, like a counter deck or a bounce deck. Turn that Ponder into a three mana for two cards.

Not the most efficient card, but has the potential to replace each spell you play with another card. Just need a lot of mana, I suppose. Blue green potential.

29934: Unifying Theory.author: Gandlodder
29934: Unifying Theory.text_parsed:
Makes for a fairly decent combo with Rhystic Study. Either they pay an extra to draw an card and deny you yours, pay an extra and you each get a card, pay an extra so nobody gets a card, or just pay nothing and let you draw one. Combined with other things that make them pay through the nose to do anything (Patron Wizard et. all), you can put your opponent into a damned-if-you-do situation.

Also, though its hard to see here on Gatherer, the artwork here is either showing us the Cabal Patriarch dressed up as a Cephalid, or he's hiding behind the Cephalid in the artwork; you can see his the distinctive cuffs of his robe peeking out at the edge of the artwork. Shows you just who is being unified by this theory...
29934: Unifying Theory.text_posted:
Makes for a fairly decent combo with [autocard]Rhystic Study[/autocard]. Either they pay an extra [3] to draw an card and deny you yours, pay an extra [2] and you each get a card, pay an extra [1] so nobody gets a card, or just pay nothing and let you draw one. Combined with other things that make them pay through the nose to do anything ([autocard]Patron Wizard[/autocard] et. all), you can put your opponent into a damned-if-you-do situation.

I really like the flavor on this card. If your opponents won't/can't pay the price, you'll "grow stronger". Sure, I mean, it was probably a lot better back then, and it's not like it's Phyrexian Arena, but on the other hand, this doesn't kill you, and it just feels more "fun".

29935: Gravestorm.author: Salient
29935: Gravestorm.text_parsed: Black control staple. 4/5 easily. You really don't even need to run graveyard hate for this to become a "draw three" over the course of the game, though if you do run hate, consider skipping Planar Void type shenanigans and just spam Relic of Progenitus. That way, if you don't draw into Gravestorm, you can use the Relic as a : bampf all graveyards, draw a card; it's a halfway-decent cantrip on its own. Also, a Bojuka Bog is a gravestormer's best friend. Sometimes the only graveyard interactions I run are four Gravestorm and four Bojuka Bog, and this is still a 'draw three over five or six turns' kind of card. Anyone designing a rogue Mono-Black Control deck should give this serious consideration.

29936: Standstill.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
It's powerful - I don't think there can be any question of that.

The real question is, is it fun? In a duel, it will make your opponent not want to do anything, while presumably you are biding your time, building up a hand full of control-flavoured answers. This isn't a situation I'd want to put a game into *unless* I was playing with man lands to speed things along... sitting there for turns waiting to see who cracks it doesn't sound terribly thrilling.

If I had to pick a card that best exemplifies a Mexican standoff, it'd probably be this. Well, this or Pernicious Deed.

29936: Standstill.author: ratchet1215
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
@kronos

You're right, sir_dwar is wrong. Standstill is sacrificed on the RESOLUTION of the triggered ability, not when the ability goes on the stack. Only when the ability that draws you three cards resolves will Standstill cause itself to sacrifice. Stifle, Trickbind, or Voidslime would counter not only the card draw but also the sacrifice of Standstill.

Of course, playing any one of those ability counterspells just causes another instance of Standstill's triggered ability to be put on the stack on top of it, so the point is moot.

29936: Standstill.author: Gabriel422
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
This sure wasn't fun when it was in Standard. You see this come down turn two, and you either:
a) play nothing for a few turns, essentially forfeiting the game ('cause you're aggro and you always lose if the game goes long)
b) accept that they can just run four Ancestral Recalls for 1U. You play as if they didn't play a Standstill, and try to win before they can stabilize... Which usually ends up badly, 'cause well, they've just drawn three cards for two mana, and unless they're really unlucky, their hand is now full of answers.

Let's just say it was a horrible, horrible idea for a card. I'm glad these days all MaRo and friends talk about are making the game fun, and it seems they're more than aware to not print something like this again.

29936: Standstill.author: Mightyass
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
I think that after the banning of Survival of the Fittest, this card is next in line.
1) It s always a threat, never an answer.
Why they dont ban FoW? Because its needed. Same goes with other powerful cards, that are answers. However, this card never answers anything - if you cast it when youre already behind, odds are you are gonna lose. If you cast it when you re winning - you have already won.
2) It makes the games go long.
If you decide to play around it, the games are terribly long. They have already banned cards before which make the game go longer (see Top in Extended).
3) If your opponent has no way in playing around it, its a 1U: Draw three cards. Slightly worse Ancestrall Recall. Still incredibly powerful.
4) Once in play, its practically indestructible. If your opponent FoW it, you have just gained card advantage. This card is extremely powerful and definetly not fun.

If you decide to play around it, the games are terribly long. They have already banned cards before which make the game go longer (see Top in Extended).
3) If your opponent has no way in playing around it, its a 1U: Draw three cards. Slightly worse Ancestrall Recall. Still incredibly powerful.
4) Once in play, its practically indestructible. If your opponent FoW it, you have just gained card advantage. This card is extremely powerful and definetly not fun.

29936: Standstill.author: Cheza
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
This card is really good, but not "broken" per se (unless you're going first and play it on turn 1).

@ Mightyass
This card is a Concentrate with an drawback that you don't draw the cards directly... and an additional risk factor, that you might even draw NO cards as all. That's clearly worth a reduced cost.

Your statements are incorrect. Basically, this card isn't just a threat, but can be a "proactive answer" to a wrath effect or similar. In a weenie deck that isn't the fastest - like merfolk - you always have to fear that your opponent plays Pyroclasm, Wrath of God or Damnation. Since you've nearly lost the game when this happens, you have to prepare yourself. And this is what Standstill does... It gives semi-fast decks the balance to win against slower control decks.

@ "Mightyass - 2)"
It NEVER makes the game long, since it's stupid to "play around" this card. As I've said, it's a Concentrate and if you can't play a spell during your next time, it's just a longer delay until he draws the card.

@ "Mightyass - 3)"
An Ancestral Recall costs one less and draws the cards directly. I wouldn't call this "slightly worse". And if you look at the Vintage decklists, how many standstills do you see? It's legal there ... so why not add 4 copies, if it's just "slightly worse" than a Ancestral Recall?

29936: Standstill.author: blurrymadness
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
Recommendation: Always immediately play into this unless you have board advantage.

I usually try to lay down an early beater to either pressure the person who played this into casting a spell or I understand that since they laid it down early you often just play into it while they can't counter and may have to discard. If they're playing it later game it's usually lose-lose for you.

Playing *with* the card I'd probably try to get my own beater down, lay this down, and force them into using removal or giving me my cards. If your deck plays enough cards fast enough you won't over-fill your hand and will be in a dominant position.

Thusly seems best-with and worst-against aggro.

29936: Standstill.author: Aremath
29936: Standstill.text_parsed:
If you play it right, you draw 3 cards. That's a big if, and that's where this card becomes fun and interesting where Ancestral Recall is not.

Conventional wisdom says that you should just accept that blue gets to draw 3 for two mana, and play into it, but that's not always the right play.

You can also play this horribly, and spend a card to let your opponent draw 3, so it's a skill-tester for sure.

Proof that fun, interesting, intricate, and powerful cards can exist at uncommon, which is nice.

Also Shardless Agent into standstill is completely amazing in so many ways. (To forestall rules discussions, cascade happens when you cast the agent. the agent is already on the stack, so even though standstill resolves before agent, agent was cast before standstill got out.)

EDIT: @JacksonBateman: I didn't think about the fact that sun titan can get it back. that's just plain evil.

29940: Pedantic Learning.author: Mr.Wimples
29940: Pedantic Learning.text_parsed:
This card deserves a much higher rating. Just because it can't fit into any old deck doesn't make it bad.

Like aforementioned, run this with Jace's Erasure and something that reveals the top card of your library, such as Wizened Snitches or Sphinx of Jwar Isle. Whenever you draw a card, you get to take a look at the next card up; If it's a card you don't want you can mill it with the erasure, if you want the next card though you can keep it there and mill your opponent's top card instead (if it's good, that is). If your next card is a land and you don't need it, mill it then draw again. This card could be an especially efficient deck thinner if ran with Scry cards or cards with Scry-like functions such as Sage Owl. Need I not mention Crucible of Worlds; ensure a land drop almost every turn and even more card acceleration.

Now if you'll excuse me gentlemen, I'm off to build a deck.

4/5

29941: Cephalid Shrine.author: Mode
29941: Cephalid Shrine.text_parsed:
That effect is just ridiculously narrow. Admittedly, it might slow your opponent down in mill decks,
but even in that particular situation still not reliably enough. And it affects you as well.

This card could have been a relevant sideboard card if they had dropped the whole X-condition entirely and just made the card hardcounter any card that has a copy of it in the graveyard.
So basically, a cheaper Bazaar of Wonders that just triggers for cards in the graveyard.

The reason this card is that bad might be the fact that it's part of a(n already weak) cycle of enchantments that all get stronger effects when a player casts a card for each copy of it in the graveyard:
Aven Shrine (gain X life)
Cephalid Shrine (counter unless X mana is paid)
Cabal Shrine (discard X cards)
Dwarven Shrine (be dealt X damage)
Nantuko Shrine (get X 1/1 green squirrels)

There are cards you can have any amount of in your deck (Ravenous Rats and Shadowborn Apostle) that might work with the Aven and Nantuko one, but even under these extreme conditions they barely get off hand.
(As opposed to Thrumming Stone for example)

But even with those in mind (and considering they didn't exist back then), I feel like all of these could have been one-drops without being broken. Alternatively, all of their effects could have been doubled and only affected you or your opponent, and I bet still nobody would complain about them being too powerful.
