29942: Battle of Wits.author: DoctorKenneth
29942: Battle of Wits.text_parsed:
For Mr (or Ms, or Mrs, of course) Paramecium302- however late the explanation may be, here it is.

Battle of Wits is a card with it's very own archetype- or rather, deck built around it. The deck, as you can imagine, runs about 260 cards. As long as the deck can be shuffled by hand, it is legal (maybe not smart, but legal). It wins by using as many tutor cards as can be packed into it, from the Demonic, Diabolic, or Idylic to find the Battle of Wits. Then it's simply a matter of playing it. The rest of the deck is peppered with counters and control, to protect the enchantment until you win and to keep your foe from killing you before the Battle is in your hand, respectfully.

It's not exactly an easy strategy, but it's a brilliantly oddball one, and that's why I love it. Would never play with it, of course, but I respect the commitment on those who do.

29942: Battle of Wits.author: the_blind_pony
29942: Battle of Wits.text_parsed:
Clever card design. Though cleverness isn't required to design a deck around it. The deck this card belongs in, for the most part, builds itself without much intuition.

I've never used the card myself, but have seen others spend a lot of time and money (tutors are expensive) gathering the cards they needed to make this card work.

One of two things happen when they finally complete their monster-deck and play it...

One, they get bored and frustrated with drawing lands and counter spells and creature control and everything else, but their precious.

Two, they draw and play the card and learn that it's not a very fun way to win a battle after all, as expounded by their opponent/s with whispers of "cheese" and "cheap".

29943: Cabal Patriarch.author: Zoah
29943: Cabal Patriarch.text_parsed:
Well... He's not bad...

His power and toughness are high. Admittedly not high enough to completely dominate a field but hey.
Also, the additional cost to activate his ability practically means nothing.

During the battle phase it would be easy to make your creatures do a little extra damage every time one died.

Overall, he would make a nice contribution to a lot of decks I can think of. He is flexible but can still be build around, In my opinion the most important par in a card.

So:
Base rating: ***
Manna cost vs stats: -*/2
Decent ability: +*
Final rating: *** */2

A pity his ability didn't cost just one less. It would have put the card at a solid **** possibly even **** */2

29943: Cabal Patriarch.author: N03y3D33R
29943: Cabal Patriarch.text_parsed:
Definitely not a bad card, just a total pain to play as effectively as one would like.
Generally the most usable he's going to be is attacking and then proceeding to wither anything larger that blocks him at the cost of one of your creatures. I feel like the sacrifice clause and the overall cost of his abilities is what really limited his playability.
If he was printed today his ability would more likely read, sacrifice a creature or exile a creature card from a graveyard, target creature gets -2-2. He was pretty darn good back when he was printed, but at this point he's nearly outclassed by "newish" common cards like Deathspore Thallid, who cost less, don't use the legend rule, and do not require mana to use abilities whatsoever.

29945: Repentant Vampire.author: longwinded
29945: Repentant Vampire.text_parsed:
@GradiustheFox:
threshold just marks the passage of time. It doesn't care about just dead creatures -- cards can mean land or spells -- and it certainly doesn't care about dead creatures in your opponent's graveyard. If you have threshold, you've been committed to the battlefield for a certain length of time. Time enough for mutants to transform, lycanthropes to change form, and in this case for the evil to repent. Innistrad's night/day system for transform cards -- where no spells cast in a turn marks nightfall and two spells cast in a turn marks daybreak -- is a similar way to tie the passage of time to the tempo of the battle.

@Ivan_Dreka: First you use the layer system, then for effects that are in the same layer you care about timestamp order. They're both color changing effects, so which ever came into effect last is the one that sticks. The threshold ability here is phrased as a static effect, which means it has the same timestamp as the permanent on it. (In other words, cast the vampire after Darkest Hour is on the battlefield, and it will be white or black depending on the state of your graveyard. If it comes in first, Darkest Hour assures that it's always black.

Aside from that, this particular card is also notable for being half of the art in a Buffy/Angel tribute (the other half being Gallantry), and in being a cute prelude to Torment's Possessed creature cycle: Possessed Nomad, Possessed Centaur, Possessed Barbarian, and Possessed Aven.

29947: Braids, Cabal Minion.author: scumbling1
29947: Braids, Cabal Minion.text_parsed:
"how come this is banned in EDH?"

It was far too easy to rush out an early Braids, along with a recurring permanent or resource, using all the fast mana available to black. EDH decks are generally focused on playing the long game, with higher CMC spells than you'd see in other formats. They just weren't equipped to deal with breaking a lock in the first few turns. Plus, EDH is a casual format, where players tend to frown upon such styles of play (at least the players who aren't sociopaths).

29950: Bloodcurdler.text_parsed:
They encircle graveyards during Rites of Initiation. Their bone chilling cries only silenced when all of their mouths are feasting on the dead.

I have a playset of these in my rites deck, one in foil, alongside other horrors like Boneshard Slasher , Frightcrawler , and Mesmeric Fiend . When I have enough nightmares, horrors, spirits, I dump my hand and swing for usually 20+. I do not rely on him to give me threshold, but see him more as another black evasive creature that gets a slight boost. 29952: Nefarious Lich.author: RJTheDestroyer
29952: Nefarious Lich.text_parsed:
It's usable if you're running a Black/White deck and have Elspeth, Knight-Errant and get off her ultimate ability making all your stuff indestructable. So, as long as your opponent doesn't bust out a remove target permanent/enchantment from the game card you won't have to worry about Nefarious Lich being destroyed, and you probably won't be taking any damage from creatures since your guys can chump block all day without dying (unless they have trample or something), so you won't need to have a huge graveyard.

But yeah, this card is very difficult to use without screwing yourself over under normal circumstances and it's cons outweigh the pros in my opinion. I'll give it a 2/5 though I think.

29952: Nefarious Lich.author: Mode
29952: Nefarious Lich.text_parsed:
FugimSky, i'll try to solve your problem.
Consider donating this card to your opponent ;)

Yet you'll unfortunately still need some further help.
Ensure to empty his/her graveyard if needed, do so by using Tormod's Crypt, Relic of Progenitus, the weaker version Scrabbling Claws, or the even weaker version Phyrexian Furnace. But overall, at least the first two "duplicates" are still very useful for emtying the graveyard.
Jund Charm and Haunting Echoes, although those are less adviseable for the sole purpose of removing the graveyard.

Well, then you'll still need your opponent to take some further tiny damage from anywhere, and then game is yours.

Oh, and Immortal Coil triggers losing the game in the same way, so you might want to use that one as well when playing a Donate deck like this.

The quadruple-black cost of Nefarious Lich is quite a mess in a multi-colored deck, but given that you only need a single blue mana for donate, it's possibly not such a great threat.

29952: Nefarious Lich.author: Dryht
29952: Nefarious Lich.text_parsed:
I love this card. Years ago I would break it out in casual formats to make people laugh but it actually had one of the best combos available:

Zombie Infestation: Discard 2 cards to create a zombie army. Then Confessor gives you 2 life and Nefarious Lich thus draws you 2 more cards - you don't need to have an ulimited army but it would probably make your opponent concede unless he can destroy the Lich on the next turn.

Cards that enhance the combo:
Anger Stick a mountain in your deck and play it for one purpose only - haste with anger. You only need 1 mountain and 1 anger and if the mountain is not in play you can simply wait to play a land until after you fish it up using the combo.
Legacy Weapon This makes the combo infinite to make people cede without having to declare attackers!

29952: Nefarious Lich.author: blurrymadness
29952: Nefarious Lich.text_parsed:
Gonna try this with Illusions of Granduer and black mana ramp cards. The ramp cards help you get to this early game and also are always splashable, making the heavy color reqs not so bad. Illusions comes out the same turn giving you 20 cards. Combo out to a Tendrils of Agony with your ramp cards and you have a T3 win, maybe T2. You will nearly deck yourself doing this mind you; however if you hit your opponent for lethal he should lose before you resolve all of the replacement draws (I think), even if you overextend your tendrils. You could use non-storm cards to do this as well, such as Sorin's Vengeance.

For convenience:
-Cabal Ritual
-Dark Ritual
-Culling the Weak
-Cloud of Faeries

Maybes:
-Songs of the Damned
-Rain of Filth

29957: Zombie Infestation.author: Ashamed
29957: Zombie Infestation.text_parsed:
It would be impossible to get 34 2/2 Zombies out on Turn 3 with that strategy.
Turn 1> Swamp or island. (7 cards in hand)
Turn 2> Land you haven't played before.> Zombie infestation. (6 cards in hand)
Turn 3> Zombie Infestation ability to discard 3 pairs of cards to get three 2/2 tokens> Treasure hunt to draw every land in your deck and one of the bottom non-land cards.(Before you draw you have 0 cards in hand)> Draw 45 (If your opening hand consisted of land cards.)> Discard 44 to get 22 Zombies. Or if your opening hand was zombie infestations and treasure hunts you would draw 51 cards getting about 25 zombies.
Now assuming all your other Zombie Infestation cards are on the bottom (along with Treasure Hunts)
that would be the most you could get: 28.

No one would play with you after this. :|

Also, Pithing Needle, lol. xD

29958: Skeletal Scrying.author: Ligerman30
29958: Skeletal Scrying.text_parsed:
This is a very powerful 1 shot effect for EDH depending on the deck

This can good because:
1) you can leave up your other instants
2) you have the opportunity to play all of the cards you drew.
3) for X cards is nuts even by blue standards.

This can hurt you because:
1)Graveyard Exile can be rough if cast for too much
2)Life loss can be rough if cast for too much

My recommendation is to run this with all the fetch lands in your colors and either run with life gain or just do it until your hand is refilled. A graveyard based deck wouldn't touch this, but if trimming down the size of your graveyard without removing key players isn't going to do much then you should be fine to run this. The deck I run can also just mill itself with little to no cost, which was a factor that pushed me in this direction.

4/5 for the decks that want it

29962: Pardic Miner.author: The_Murderauder
29962: Pardic Miner.text_parsed: @wholelottalove: They can't. Playing a land is a special action that can only be done on your turn, during one of your main phases, when the stack is empty, and can't be responded to because it doesn't use the stack. That's not what this card is for. You're supposed to crack this on your opponent's upkeep. That prevents him from playing a land for the rest of the turn.

29963: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.author: allmighty_abacus
29963: Kamahl, Pit Fighter.text_parsed: I think sometimes it is best to think of discrepancies in power and toughness as being a reflection of how reckless someone is, instead of how much armor someone is wearing. All the plate armor in the world isn't going to help much if you immediately rush the largest formation closest to you. Kamahl is a barbarian legend with a giant two-handed sword- he doesn't want to waste time thinking about his opponents' counterattack! That is time better spent hewing them limb from limb! As a direct result he is reckless, and prone to counterattack.

29966: Savage Firecat.author: DoctorKenneth
29966: Savage Firecat.text_parsed:
Reckless Charge makes it a 9/5, with the mana tapping and all. Brute Force may be better for what you're thinking, making it 9/9. You won't be flashing back the charge anyway.

Setting it up with haste is nice. Doubling it up with a pre-set enchantment like Gratuitous Violence would be nice as well, though the curve is a little iffy on that one.

Maybe you can pack some Simian Spirit Guides or mana-artifacts to play around him, but that seems like a lot of hoops for some extra aggression. Could work, though.

29966: Savage Firecat.author: achilleselbow
29966: Savage Firecat.text_parsed:
Actually Duriele is right. You can float 6 mana before casting anything, and then drop the Firecat and the Reckless Charge right after. It won't lose any counters and it'll get +3/+0 and haste, so it will indeed be a 10/7.

Even without tricks like that the drawback isn't as much of a problem as you'd think. You probably don't have to worry about casting anything else the turn that you drop this, and the next turn you can attack before doing anything else. Most likely your opponent won't have any creatures that can match it unless they're playing green. Either they take a hefty amount of damage and then you decide whether to cast something at the cost of losing a couple of counters (and even then a 5/5 or 4/4 trample isn't something to laugh at), or they'll drop some removal and leave you free to cast other stuff. Either way, the drawback doesn't really hurt you at all.

29971: Need for Speed.author: EvilDarkVoid
29971: Need for Speed.text_parsed:
Pretty niche use, but this is actually good for early game kills with giant monsters if you don't expect to have spare mana the turn you cast them, but you do expect to have spare red mana earlier. For example:

t1 Mountain, Need for Speed
t2 Island, tap the Mountain for Sol Ring, tap the Sol Ring and Island to Tinker out a Blightsteel Colossus, sac a land and swing for probably game.

Its hardly overpowered in and of itself; its just that it can do pretty well with actually overpowered cards such as Sol Ring, Tinker, and Blightsteel Colossus.

29972: Molten Influence.author: scumbling1
29972: Molten Influence.text_parsed:
Red still falls short of the critical threshold of counterspells to make a 'draw go' deck. Unitl a time where one can assemble such a thing, Molten Influence is pretty much useless.

Once someone can make a red permission deck, Molten Influence will still be a bad card, though. The opponent will always opt to take the damage until it would kill them. Control decks don't put pressure on an opponent's life total until they are ready to tackle the whole amount with a single creature or combo -- they don't piece together twenty damage opportunisitically. Therefore, Molten Influence will never work in a way that's beneficial to it's caster.

29972: Molten Influence.author: majinara
29972: Molten Influence.text_parsed:
It's bad for the same reasons as dash hopes.

This is like a burn spell, that will never kill a player. When a player is at four life or something, they will let you just counter the spell. Any other burn spell might kill them, but this one won't.

And it's like a counterspell, that will never counter their really important spells. The oppponent is about the assemble his winning combo in some combo deck? What does he care about being dealt four damage? If the spell resolves, he wins.

It also doesn't fit into any strategy except "random junk deck". In a burn or aggro deck, you don't want to keep mana open to wait for an opponent to maybe play an instant or sorcery that is important enough to have your opponent be dealt four damage. And in a control deck, you want to be able to control what your opponent is doing. This won't let you do that.

It's like a lightning bolt, that deals 1 more damage, but can't kill creatures, can't kill players, can only be played in response to instants and sorcery. That deals damage when you don't want it to, and counters when you don't want it to.

29972: Molten Influence.author: endersblade
29972: Molten Influence.text_parsed:
I have a casual deck that I use this in. It's basically nothing but counterspells and burn spells. Very basic, I know. It takes the place of two cards - a burn spell and a counterspell. When running two colors that are good at doing one of the other, it's always nice to save space where you can. Quite obviously, either your opponent takes 4, or you counter his spell. Simple. Sure, people always rally behind 'but giving your opponent a choice sucks!', but I actually find it rather tormenting :-)

If they take the damage, they are that much closer to to dying. If you counter the spell instead, you're one more spell away from death. Obviously you wouldn't hold out with this spell and try to counter something at some critical point in the game, where they will just take the damage and kill you that turn. If you do that, you are a retarded magic player and I feel bad for whoever plays against you. You play this on something that might not be much of a threat. THAT is when the choice matters.

29972: Molten Influence.author: LordRandomness
29972: Molten Influence.text_parsed:
There's a big difference between this and Dash Hopes: This is red. You can cast it on a powerful spell with enough burn to surprise kill them if they take the damage, which isn't that unlikely in a burn deck. Then you either win or they lose their important spell, and you'd be surprised how often you get the "win" outcome from that.

Basically: Giving the opponent choices is often bad, but forcing the opponent to make choices with incomplete information can be a viable tactic if you're good at bluffing.

29973: Price of Glory.author: crenel
29973: Price of Glory.text_parsed: This is arguably the best in Blue/Red decks due to the nature of several Blue counter abilities (i.e. "Counter target spell unless its controller pays (X)", Force Spike). There's nothing quite as satisfying to me as saying, "Either I snuff one of your most important spells or you lose out on extra land." Of course it defeats the purpose of traditional Blue/Red which allows you to cast during an opponent's turn, but when played right it's quite humorous.

29973: Price of Glory.author: Aaron_Forsythe
29973: Price of Glory.text_parsed:
Aaron's Random Card Comment of the Day #20, 10/22/10

Another day, another red enchantment meant to hose counterspells without explicitly saying so. Price of Glory was released one year after the last card I talked about that did this, Monday’s Tectonic Instability. I guess R&D was having serious trouble with counterspell decks at that time and found the best way to hose them was with nasty hate like this.

Despite being almost strictly worse than the paragon of control-hosers, City of Solitude, this one at least did its job. R&D knew it was going to have an impact, as it was previewed on the now-defunct Sideboard.com by one Brian Kibler nine years ago. I’ve seen it in various sideboards in Standard decks from that era, and there was a time where this was showing up in Vintage sideboards as well. Not only is it good against counters, but anything that might require mana on an opponents’ turn, like activating a Circle of Protection: Red or regenerating a Nightscape Familiar (as is City of Solitude, as is Tectonic Instability).

Besides that, the similarities between this and Tectonic Instability are so great (same mana cost on top of everything else I’ve listed) that I’m having a hard time finding an angle to discuss. I guess this one is somewhat significant because it isn’t rare. Literally the only comment on Multiverse regarding this card is by one Randy Buehler, notorious counterer of spells, proclaiming “Ouch!” I guess the card merited about as much discussion when it was being made as it does now.

A tip of the hat to Gaussgoat for pointing out the combo with Drain Power (although his combo of Price of Glory + Mana Short doesn't work)and XTwistedsoulX for comboing this with Fade Away. In the true spirit of Johnny, clever uses can be found for just about anything.

29973: Price of Glory.author: DHThomas
29973: Price of Glory.text_parsed:
I had this card played against me once. I was playing Psychatog in Standard(and had that little Grinning Buscemi in play) when my opponent decided to cast this card. My kneejerk reaction was to counter it at all costs. Luckily, I decided to actually look at the game state and do some math. I said 'Sure' and let it resolve. When my opponent said go, I got rid of anything in the way and tapped a few other lands to get them in the yard. Untap, swing with Psychatog for exactsies by removing all those lands that were now in my graveyard.

My opponent was less than happy with this chain of events.

29978: Chance Encounter.author: Cisnero
29978: Chance Encounter.text_parsed:
So many ways to win, so little time...

Karplusan Minotaur... so many coins flying around!
Krark's Thumb... obvious staple combo card!
Fighting Chance+Goblin tokens=Look! If they block my 1/1 creatures, either Chance Encounter is fueled, or there's no harm to my creatures, no loss!
Goblin Bomb: Tick tick tick tick...
Squee's Revenge: More piles of coins!
Skyclaw Thrash: Possible 5/5 flyer AND coins!


Yeah, it's an uphill battle, for sure. But refer to the card's flavor text. :)

29978: Chance Encounter.author: kitsunewarlock
29978: Chance Encounter.text_parsed:
4 turn auto-wins with Frenetic Efreet. Very broken, and since your playing blue and red you get plenty of removal the first 3 turns in the form of burn (if you focus your burn on creatures, it can take you quite far) and plenty of counter-spells.

Unfortunately Blue and Red don't have any good creature or enchantment search. Blue does have amazing draw though. And they ally with Black, which has omni-search.

4 Frenetic Efreet
4 Chance Encounter
4 Daze
4 Force of Will
4 Pact of Negation
4 Lightning Bolt
4 Ponder
4 Brainstorm
4 Electrolize

4 Chrome Mox

4 Volcanic Island
4 Steam Vents
4 "Fetch Land"
4 Island
4 Mountain

Side:
4 Shattering Spree (against Pithing Needle)
4 Relic of Progenitus
4 Pithing Needle
2 Tormod's Crypt

29979: Squirrel Mob.author: GrimjawxRULES
29979: Squirrel Mob.text_parsed:
With the arrival of Changelings, Squirrel decks just got a long-awaited update. Many cards in the Lorwyn turns your creatures into changelings (Shields of Velis-Vel, Mirror Entity), and since squirrels and their "lords" are really limited in number, one might think about recruiting some changeling help from the Lorwyn plane.

Squirrel Mob has one of the most hilarious flavor texts I've ever seen on a card. You wouldn't normally expect to be ripped to pieces by a large mob of squirrels, but as the flavor text dictates; "An army of squirrels is still an army" xD
29979: Squirrel Mob.text_posted:

Squirrel Mob has one of the most hilarious flavor texts I've ever seen on a card. You wouldn't normally expect to be ripped to pieces by a large mob of squirrels, but as the flavor text dictates; "[i]An army of squirrels is still an army[/i]" xD

29982: Terravore.author: Lateralis0ne
29982: Terravore.text_parsed:
Talaxar:

My friend rolls a {W}{B}{G} land lock deck, and he used this to great effect in a game with me once. I was running a STAX/Land Lock variant, he a simple land lock with Crucible, Strip Mine, Exploration and a few other key cards. We had the board locked for 25 turns without either of us gaining any ground, until he Regrowth'd his second ordeal after Balancing and Twisting me, swinging for around 30 and getting rid of the rest of my library.

Don't get me wrong; a {R}{G} land destruction deck is simple and effective. But {W} and {B} can make a very viable landkill deck as well.

29983: Stone-Tongue Basilisk.author: humor_love
29983: Stone-Tongue Basilisk.text_parsed:
Not the best card for its mana (certainly not any more), but it's fun to play.

Card sets that came out around this time were the beginning of the end of old or original Magic. You would never have seen a creature like this in Revised (C-ckatrice), Ice Age (Scaled Wurm), or The Dark. Legends might have had a Legend creature similar to this (though, likely with a worse efficiency : power ratio), but then it would be a Legend and not a possible 3- or 4-packer.

If he cost less, he'd be a lot better than the 3 stars I gave him.

29984: Zoologist.author: endersblade
29984: Zoologist.text_parsed:
I run this in my Mayael EDH deck. As contrary as that seems, this card is actually pretty good. Sometimes I don't have the full open to use mayael's ability. This guy's ability is mono-green, costs two less, and is less detrimental to your play style than mayael. (She essentially 'mills' several cards from the top of your deck every time you use her; even though they just go to the bottom, you still don't get to use them.) If you have Crysal Ball, Sensei's Divining Top, Mirri's Guile, or any other top-deck manipulation to use, this guy is amazing. It's instant speed, so you can use it in response to someone doing something, like attacking.

Another card to look at which does something similar, but is more forgiving and less mana intensive, is Lurking Predators.

29985: Seton, Krosan Protector.author: Ferlord
29985: Seton, Krosan Protector.text_parsed:
At first I thought Druid's weren't a strong enough tribal.

But in truth, a lot of the good druid's are actually good Elves. The problem with that is most Elf Druid's already have an ability that is somewhere along the lines of, ": Add to your mana pool".

Mind you, there are still a few Druid's that don't have an activated ability that work well with this: Argothian Enchantress, Joiner Adept, Gilt-Leaf Archdruid, Yavimaya Elder, Treefolk Harbinger, Nantuko Cultivator, and lest we forget the Squirrel lords Nut Collector and Squirrel Wrangler.

If you want to do something different, making a Mono-Green EDH deck with him as your general won't be a bad idea. It won't be too expensive to maintain.

29985: Seton, Krosan Protector.author: Kirbster
29985: Seton, Krosan Protector.text_parsed:
The fact that he gives all of your little druids "haste" can be a very big deal for one reason: Gilt-Leaf Archdruid. Play a one-mana druid (Llanowar Elves, Fyndhorn Elves, Arbor Elf, Elvish Mystic), draw a card (probably another druid), tap your elf right away to play the new one, wash, rinse, repeat. Easy.
Don't forget that Elvish Harbinger is also a druid and can fetch you whatever elf you want to draw. Another druid, sure, but something like Ezuri, Renegade Leader will give you a way to win with all of those one-drops you sent out. Don't forget that the Archdruid also lets you take all of your opponent's lands to keep him or her from stopping you before you go for the kill!

29985: Seton, Krosan Protector.author: deep_shadow
29985: Seton, Krosan Protector.text_parsed: Seton is one of my favourite creatures in my druids deck. When I first looked at the card, I was disappointed that he was a "more expensive" Heritage Druid, and especially by his being a 2/2. Functionally, however, the card is incredibly efficient, considering cards like Nykthos, Shrine to Nyx and Green Sun's Zenith exist. Often times, Seton functions as a "free cost" card that can add to your devotion right before a Nykthos activation, or sometimes even as an emergency reserve of mana that you can tutor for. His ability more than makes up for his casting cost, and I give him a well earned 4.5/5.

29986: Chlorophant.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
29986: Chlorophant.text_parsed:
PlayerGreen, Ideatog, you both make good points about this guy's effectiveness.

I have to second the fact that this guy really misses trample - a lot - but he's still an interesting design. In the early game green can do much better than a 1/1 for 3 (even at you've got Leatherback Baloth and Groundbreaker), but if he can sit unmolested for a few turns then he may make up for that.

More interesting is the way they've used threshold here - it helps compensate for drawing a small creature in the late game if he grows twice as fast.

29989: Verdant Succession.author: pumaman83
29989: Verdant Succession.text_parsed:
A long shot combo but you can use Verdant Succession, Gamekeeper, Elvish Soultiller, Riftsweeper, and a sacrifice outlet to put every creature in your deck in play. And it is a lot easier because three of those are elves which means good use of Wirewood Herald could put them all into your hand.

Verdant Succession, Gamekeeper, Elvish Soultiller, and sac outlet in play. Sacrifice Gamekeeper to trigger playing first creature from library and then trigger Verdant Succession. Then cast Riftsweeper to shuffle 1st Gamekeeper back in. Repeat until the last Riftsweeper is in play and then sac Soultiller to put all the Riftsweepers back in. Eventually you should have nearly the whole deck in play.

29994: Holistic Wisdom.author: Fictionarious
29994: Holistic Wisdom.text_parsed:
How about this:
Turn the drawback into a benefit.

Have a couple of these and four Sterling Groves for finding them and protecting them. Two Gaea's Blessing for perpetual playability. And two Plague Wind to wipe your opponent's field and swing with your creature tokens. The rest of the deck, only instants.

4 Manamorphose for card drawing and mana fixing.
4 Pull from Eternity to get any card you've previously exiled with Wisdom back into your graveyard where it can be retrieved again (from the exile zone to your hand at instant speed for three mana).
4 Krosan Grip because its the best at what it does thanks to split second.
4 Tolarian Winds so you can get a new hand whenever you want while putting all of your previous hand into your graveyard to be retrieved if you need it later.
4 Moment's Peace. Play it from hand, play it from graveyard, get it back from exile eventually.
2 Angel's Grace for nearly perpetual immunity to losing
4 Beast Attack to build up beast creature tokens mid-to-late game

Overall that's 10 non-instants, 24 lands, and the rest instants.
Best I could do.

30005: Catalyst Stone.author: Chrs84
30005: Catalyst Stone.text_parsed:
Well, this is one way to guarantee success for a particular theme/gameplay (flashback). 5 stars for exactly what it creates, which is the option to use flashback cards with awesome effects but that normally cost an unrealistic amount of mana to play and/or flashback.
Secondly, you can reduce already cheap flashback costs so that you can overwhelm your opponent with volume of spells.
Thirdly, screw your opponent by increasing the amount they have to spend to run their flashback themes.
The mana cost to play this spell is perfect. The flavour text is perfect.

30010: Mossfire Egg.author: superboi
30010: Mossfire Egg.text_parsed:
Ruling - " This is a mana ability, which means it can be played as part of the process of playing a spell or another ability. If that happens you get the mana right away, but you don't get to look at the drawn card until you have finished playing that spell or ability."

What if I didn't use the mana for anything, but I activated the ability anyway? Do I get to draw a card still? Wouldn't it be that the first part is a mana ability, and the second part goes on the stack?

30010: Mossfire Egg.author: KMcombine
30010: Mossfire Egg.text_parsed:
The art is amazing, to the point that these eggs would look to be great collectors items if they did exist, the flavor text is great, shame they aren't so great compared to whats on the market.

Otherwise; colour fixing and Draw card for CMC
Salvaging Station to retrieve this when you sac it and suddenly you have a : sac for & Draw card.

Woah just realised, with "MotM" March of the Machines active this becomes a 1/1 creature, tap saccing would activate the untap condition for Salvaging station allowing you to infinitely salvage this card and sac it, provided there's a Haste Mechanic in play like Concordant Crossroads you can now draw as much cards as you want :)!

Not bad, not great but a piece of Otarias history, nice job wizards... its cards like these that flesh out the multiverse of mtg and keep the rest looking great but in their own right all cards are gems.

I also think you best run this card along with the legendary Urza's Saga lands cycle which add one mana of a certain color for each specific type of permanent you control; being Serra's Sanctum, (Tolarian Academy - Vintage-only,) and Gaea's Cradle. Minamo also does a great job here by the way
Further cards you could use with the temple are Urza's Tower when using the Urzathrone, Cabal Coffers or maybe Cloudpost.
You could of course just use any special land that does something different than just producing mana, although most of the time since those abilities also require mana this will only be useful in lategame.
Aside from that, this card has a very amiable artwork in my opinion.

30013: Deserted Temple.author: MacBizzle
30013: Deserted Temple.text_parsed:
Hardly recognized you there, Tolarian Academy.

@Ava_Adore:
You don't need 3+ different cards to break it. You need Tolarian Academy (or the other two from its cycle), Cabal Coffers or any other land that on its own produces an indefinite amount of mana.
Anytime I hear people mentioning the "a-card-needing-other-cards-to-be-good-is-a-bad-card" argument, I suddenly realize that that person has never seen a properly assembled combo deck. If you have one card that provides a very specific purpose, you're building your combo wrong. If you have a card that gives about 3 purposes, and you have fallback cards (in case some ass actually runs scour, quash, eradicate, sowing salt, splinter, etc.) in the deck. Example: I don't need four expedition maps and four tolaria wests in my deck; however, in doing so, I can cut down my tolarian academies to two (considering only one) and still have a really good chance of drawing it. In addition, expedition map adds to my artifact count (making tolarian academy tap for one more every turn), tolaria west can find any land (or 0 cost artifact, adding to a free storm and adding an additional mana to tolarian academy), and when my academy is already out, I can use the expedition maps and tolaria wests to find more of this guy.

THAT, is synergy. Which really is just a properly assembled combo deck. The combo pieces don't NEED each other, they just complement each other.

30013: Deserted Temple.author: casualhorror

It's usefulness scales inversely with how powerful the land you are comboing it with is. Remember, a land that taps for infinite and one that taps for 21 are exactly the same when you are killing someone at 20 (with no hand and no board presence) with a Fireball.

30015: Tarnished Citadel.author: Evil_Tactics
30015: Tarnished Citadel.text_parsed:
I gave this 3.5/5 for a reason.
People are comparing this to City of Brass, which is fine. Overall Brass is more efficient if you're not trying to kill yourself as fast for colored mana.

However, keep in mind that at the worst case scenario other than outright killing yourself, you can still tap this for 1 colorless, and this land doesn't enter the battlefield tapped.

All of that aside, players have to recognize this land as a combo land. Obviously you're not going to play this over City of Brass for straight up color use. This is the only land that will give you optional painfree mana when you don't want to hurt yourself, yet can deal 3 damage to you when you WANT it to. Yes Tamanoa works okay if you combo in lifegain triggers, but currently as mentioned previously it's all about Darien, King of Kjeldor.

No other land will easily deal 3 damage to yourself while giving yourself any color mana. That's 3 1/1 soldier tokens at instant speed, and if you combo in either Essence Warden, Soul Warden, and/or Soul's Attendant you can get even more life back than you lost.

This land is best at what it can do, it shouldn't be rated so badly just cause it has specialized use. This is a combo land, nothing more. Heck, the Grand Coliseum variant of this that enters the battlefield tapped, that is even worse if you compare it to City of Brass. This land deserves at least higher than a 2, it fills a useful niche that no other land achieves.

30015: Tarnished Citadel.author: yuvalg
30015: Tarnished Citadel.text_parsed:
I actually think this is better than City of Brass if you're playing it in a mostly colorless or artifact deck, where most of the time you're fine with colorless mana but occasionally need it for whatever multi-color spells you may have.

It's also fine in EDH in my opinion, where the 3 damage doesn't hurt as much and you need more land variety due to the singleton rule. And if we combine the two ideas - a mostly colorless EDH deck e.g. Sharuum - well then, we have a winner!

30547: Epicenter.author: Alchemix
30547: Epicenter.text_parsed:
Super bad combo:
Hive Mind
Sigarda. Host of Herons
Epicenter
Naturalize
Counterspell

1. Have Hive Mind and Sigarda out
2. Cast Epicenter, have it copied by opponent
3. Naturalize the Hive Mind
4. Counter your own Epicenter, choose not to pay
5. Opponent now controls the effect, so because of Sigarda it can't cause you to sacrifice permanents.

* NB: Requires Threshold for opponent. Mind Sculpt them if necessary.
* NB: Can be done without Naturalize/Counterspell combo if you don't have Threshold and they do.

30549: Krosan Beast.author: GrimjawxRULES
30549: Krosan Beast.text_parsed:
People seem to be missing the point. The art does not depict the squirrel - it depicts the beast the squirrel has become.
The reason squirrels (and anything else that lives in the forest of Krosa for that matter) turn into monsters is because of all the mana. You could think of the threshold mechanic as mana accu'mulating in your graveyard (fits the flavor of the card, since time passes before the mutation is complete) and affecting your creatures and spells.

30552: Entomb.author: apollogod
30552: Entomb.text_parsed:
This card would be amazing even at sorcery speed. One black mana to tutor ANY card and drop it directly into my graveyard? Yes, please!

But wait, there's more! You can do all of that, still for one black mana, at instant speed! You read that right! Instant speed tutor for 1 black mana. Did I mention there are NO drawbacks to this card?

I love graveyard strategies, especially reanimator decks. This card allows for some amazing and outrageous turn 1 plays. Ritual + Entomb + Exhume has been mentioned already, and it is a wonderful combo. I also enjoy Ritual + Thoughtseize + Entomb + Reanimate. Sure, you're down a lot of life. But you have a bombastic creature and you perhaps stole a wincon from the opp. That's an A+ turn 1 if I ever saw one!

Anyone who rates this card less than a 5 really has no idea of what this card is capable.

5/5

30552: Entomb.author: landboysteve
30552: Entomb.text_parsed:
One night...the WOTC design team got together for a night of drinking and brainstorming for new cards. Unfortunately, there was more drinking than designing.

But at the end of the night...when everybody was plastered out of their minds...the conversation went something like this.

WOTC Designer 1: Hey, why don't we make a card where somebody can go into their deck and pull out any card they want and just toss it in the graveyard?

WOTC Designer 2: Why would we want to do that?

WOTC Designer 1: Just to *** people off.

WOTC Designer 3: What color? And what would be the casting cost?

WOTC Designer 1: Black. And what the ****...let's make it a casting cost of 1 and an instant to boot.

WOTC Designer 4: (burp) Sounds ****ing great to me. Hell...let's do it.

And that's how this broken to hell card came to be.

30555: Ancestral Tribute.author: DarthParallax
30555: Ancestral Tribute.text_parsed:
What I like about this card is how it looks, at first glance, like a pretty small effect.

It's got an old frame.

And the mana cost is absurdly high and color dense.

In other words, it looks ancient. It's primitive. It's almost obsolete.
.........

.........

And it's really, really, powerful. Cards like this teach you the game. Like Necropotence. Necropotence is, from the narrowest perspective, a Howling Mine on lots and lots of crack. This is Healing Salve on lots and lots and LOTS of crack. Cards like that....they're just so simple, but in a resoundingly colossal way. Like a volcanic eruption. The opposite of cards like Time Reversal, which just does a lot of stuff in general, and the textbox would SOUND impressive even without the 'PHENOMENAL COSMIC POWER' artwork. This does almost nothing, and it's still daunting to read. I don't know if I said what I wanted to say. Being eloquent is kind of the opposite of the idea of stuff like this. It's like a reverse Fireball. Pump a horribly inefficient amount of mana into a giant spell, but you know what? It wins you the game when you do it right.



One of these days, I really want to see someone use Fireball like a Wrath of God, against an army of actually tough creatures, like 3/3s, 4/4s and up. I just really really want someone decide to actually pump that much mana into Fireball. I think it would be totally awesome :)

30556: Traumatize.author: Ideatog
30556: Traumatize.text_parsed:
@ kilovortex: Indeed. I've been on the receiving end of that dick move multiple times. Not really fun.

Now don't get me wrong, Traumatize is a great card. However, aside from not being very fun for the victim, it also disrupts the game overmuch. With normal mill like Tome Scour or Glimpse the Unthinkable you just count off the top X cards. With Traumatize, the receiving player has to count his library without looking at it or changing the order and then mill X cards.

In practice, more annoying than anything, especially since most players just scoop afterward anyway.
30556: Traumatize.text_posted:

30556: Traumatize.author: OmegaSerris
30556: Traumatize.text_parsed:
@Ideatog

If you are playing casually, just sort your deck into two piles. Alternate putting the top card of your deck into one pile at a time. Keep in mind the pile you start with, this one will be your deck. The second pile goes to the graveyard. See, if you have an even number of cards, the piles will be equal so it doesn't matter. If you have an odd number, the first pile will be the pile you should end with, hence be the 'rounded up' (one more card) pile making the second the 'rounded down.'

Sounds more complicated than it is, but my friend played Mill in EDH. This method got me through my EDH deck in under a minute. Again, this is a casual thing, since deck order isn't taken into account. If you know the top or bottom order of cards, you probably want to do things the hard way.

30556: Traumatize.author: blurrymadness
30556: Traumatize.text_parsed:
It's alright. Unfortunately this is an expensive card to cast and *can never* finish the game, meaning that you go through the excruciating practice of counting your deck, then counting half your deck off for little effect. IMO if you're doing it for the sake of milling, I'd recommend building around sanity grinding or just cheap mill cards.

That said, aside from counting, this is a fun effect and really flashy; but most of the time you'll get more cards out of a T1 hedron crab or so. They should only be at ~20 cards by T5 anyway making this a glimpse the unthinkable

My very first deck was a combo deck filled with Clockspinning, Living End, and Traumatize and tons of off-color slivers. It was pretty bad.

30556: Traumatize.author: KiteX3
30556: Traumatize.text_parsed: @OmegaSerris As an improvement on that method: pick up your library, then alternate between placing the bottom card of that pile face-down back onto your library pile and the top card of that pile into your graveyard. With that modification, the method matches every technical detail of Traumatize while also avoiding any time-consuming counting; though I do estimate it requires a bit more dexterity, and explaining the method to a stranger will probably negate any time savings.

30570: Firebolt.author: blurrymadness
30570: Firebolt.text_parsed:
This might seem odd, but this is another reason I really like legacy over modern. Geistflame is alright and we can bicker about sorcery vs. instant all day; but let me say that if you mix sorcery and instant then you get the benefits of both more damage and instant speed. Case in point, mix this with Lava Dart if anything. It nails creatures you don't want to waste bolts on, and it does it repeatedly.

Another difference is that it's 4 damage in 1 card, which is always good. Geistflame is 2 damage in one card, as with lava dart; which to me implies a sideboard card. This can be main'd in a sligh deck because it can hit 2 blockers over the course of it's life, both with relevant toughnesses. You're supposed to be the aggro player anyway in most match ups.

30572: Scorching Missile.author: Henrietta
30572: Scorching Missile.text_parsed:
First, rarity is honestly irrelevant to 'strictly' arguments, as are unusual formats. It's a direct comparison between the gameplay aspects of the cards. It's like saying a plains is better than a black lotus because plains are easier to obtain. As for formats like Pauper and EDH, I don't see why they should be counted because they start as house rules and anyone can make a format where a card might be better than it would be otherwise. I can create my own format where the only extra rule is cards you cast must have a minimum cmc of 7. Does this unusual format make a lightning bolt that costs RRRRRRR not strictly worse than a regular Lightning Bolt?

Second, this card is still not strictly worse than Flame Javelin or Flame Sash. It's automatically invalidated from being strictly worse because it has flashback, and as ridiculous as that flashback cost may be it might be useful 1 in 50 games and is thus not STRICTLY worse. There's also a second thing for each of those cards that makes it not strictly worse - Flame Javelin is more colour intensive, costing RRR or 2RR rather than 3R, and Flame Sash targets creatures rather than players. Both are SIGNIFICANTLY better, but not STRICTLY better. For strictly better, see Lightning Bolt vs. Shock or Lightning Bolt vs. Shock, or Counterspell vs. Cancel. Stuff like that.

Just my two cents on using strictly better the wrong way.

30692: Acceptable Losses.author: IshubarashI
30692: Acceptable Losses.text_parsed:
I happen to like this card, the friends I play casually with have come to fear this card, since I play it in my hellbent/madness deck. It really puts pressure on my opponents (when we discard "randomly" we just put our hand face down and have an opponent pick one) because the card they pick could easily be Call to the Netherworld, or Dark Withering, or Big Game Hunter, or at the least it could be a Reckless Wurm. I like to screw with my friends' heads by using cards like this. But I admit it's limited to what type of deck it can be played in and actually be good. I give it 2.5/5

Also, I realize Lightning Axe is a much better version of this card but I just get a kind of nostalgic feeling from using older cards like this. That being said, I only run one of these in my deck, with a play set of lightning axes

30747: Bearscape.author: Wraique
30747: Bearscape.text_parsed:
Lmfao! Really? Bearscape?

First I read the ability, and thought 'Hm. Guess it's ok. Might be hard to get that many lands into your graveyard though.'

Then I read the name of the card. Bearscape. 'Lol. What's the picture gonna be, a mountain range of bear's coming to l-'

Then I looked at the picture, and indeed it WAS mountain range, in animate bear form, with what looks like a little naked person shouting at the bears. I lolled. I lolled heartily.

"Nature is in the endless dance between bear and mountain. Makes sense when you really sit back and think about it." - Seton, centaur druid

Edit: Whoops. Yeah, lands is wrong.

30749: Darkwater Egg.author: KMcombine
30749: Darkwater Egg.text_parsed:
the artworks on these cards were so amazing, this card in particular I remember cracking and was bedazzled by the art, still wondering why the rules weren't as great.
well since my and my brother played for pleasure and read up on most of the mtg lore, playing this card and soaking in the flavor was half the fun.

Colour fixing and Draw card for CMC
Salvaging Station to retrieve this when you sac it and suddenly you have a : sac for & Draw card.

Woah just realised, with "MotM" March of the Machines active this becomes a 1/1 creature, tap saccing would activate the untap condition for Salvaging station allowing you to infinitely salvage this card and sac it, provided there's a Haste Mechanic in play like Concordant Crossroads you can now draw as much cards as you want :)!

30761: Shelter.author: Laguz
30761: Shelter.text_parsed:
Quite possibly my favorite card ever printed.

It's a counterspell for stuff targeting your creatures. It can win a game by letting something get through unblocked. It removes pacifisms and other harmful auras. It can save one of your creatures from your own board-clearing spells. It has a really hot chick with nice legs. And on top of all that...it replaces itself!

What else could you ask for, really? 4.5/5

30761: Shelter.author: tcollins
30761: Shelter.text_parsed:
Great versatity it can be used to:

1. Save a creature that was going to die due to blocking in combat (Your Serra Angel blocks Glissa, The Traitor...before damage you give your angel protection from {B})
2. Protect your creature from damage-based removal (things like Lightning Bolt)
3. Make any one creature unblockable or at least less blockable (playing against a {G} deck? Give it protection from {G})

All that and it replaces itself with a new card.

30761: Shelter.author: Mode
30761: Shelter.text_parsed:
Good strategists seize opportunities.
Great strategists make their own.

Does that make her a bad strategist?
Because judging from the image, she wasn't able to make an opportunity yet to put on any pants.
But maybe she simply did not want to.
Maybe it's even part of her plan.

Maybe she is in fact a genious master strategist, using her pantlessness to make opportunities for herself and others
by distracting the opponent this way, who keeps her (rear) in focus even though she has a cast a protection shield, while her (unprotected) allies can use their opportunity to rush through and ambush the opponent.

I conclude:

Good strategists seize opportunities.
Great strategists make their own.
Gorgeous strategists wear no pants.

30763: Cultural Exchange.author: grothesk
30763: Cultural Exchange.text_parsed: For anyone wondering, cards such as this that allow you to "choose" a creature does NOT mean you are targeting the creature. This means that you can indeed force a player (who is the actual target of the spell) to exchange their creatures with shroud and hexproof for other creatures, even "sacrifice when they become the target of a spell or ability" creatures such as Phantasmal Bear. Because you are simply CHOOSING them and not targeting the Bear simply finds himself under the control of another player.

Hey everyone,

What is the ruling when I turn this enchantment into a "creature that is still an enchantment" and then someone deals leathal dmg to said creature/enchantment. For example, if i make it a 3/3 and block a 5/5 attacking creature-- does the enchantment get destroyed and it goes into my graveyard or do I get to keep the enchanment in play (but not as a 3/3 anymore)?
30765: Testament of Faith.text_posted:
Hey everyone,

What is the ruling when I turn this enchantment into a "creature that is still an enchantment" and then someone deals leathal  dmg to said creature/enchantment. For example, if i make it a 3/3 and block a 5/5 attacking creature-- does the enchantment get destroyed and it goes into my graveyard or do I get to keep the enchanment in play (but not as a 3/3 anymore)?

30765: Testament of Faith.author: NoobOfLore
30765: Testament of Faith.text_parsed:
Mirror entity doesn't cost , and it can weaken your other creatures if you don't have the mana to sink into it.

Edit: @Doomstrike Seeing as the enchantment is now the creature, the card itself is put into the graveyard as a state-based effect. You can tell, because it says "It becomes a creature" as opposed to "Put a creature into play."
This card is the creature, the creature dies, the card it's on goes to the graveyard.
Pretty straightforward.
30765: Testament of Faith.text_posted:

Pretty straightforward.

31444: Chatter of the Squirrel.author: Arachibutyrophobia
31444: Chatter of the Squirrel.text_parsed: flashback works with nantuko shrine, right?

31444: Chatter of the Squirrel.author: Ideatog
31444: Chatter of the Squirrel.text_parsed:
@Arachibutyrophobia:

Yes and no. When you flashback a card you are casting it, so Nantuko Shrine's ability will trigger. However, since you're casting Chatter of the Squirrel, the card will be on the stack, not in your graveyard and so won't count itself. It will, however, still count other copies of Chatter of the Squirrel in your graveyard, but since using flashback exiles the card afterwards, you'll get limited mileage out of that.
31444: Chatter of the Squirrel.text_posted:
@Arachibutyrophobia:

Yes and no. When you flashback a card you [i]are casting it[/i], so [autocard]Nantuko Shrine[/autocard]'s ability will trigger. However, since you're casting Chatter of the Squirrel, the card will be on the stack, not in your graveyard and so won't count itself. It will, however, still count other copies of Chatter of the Squirrel in your graveyard, but since using flashback exiles the card afterwards, you'll get limited mileage out of that.

This is still a really nice card, and the fact that it can be used twice is really awesome.  It's always nice to see the look on your opponent's face when they forget about this, and get hit by a much larger creature late in the game.

Also, tacking [autocard]Lightning Bolt[/autocard] and haste onto a creature for [R] is really solid, because that's what it often becomes.  Even turn 0 [autocard]Memnite[/autocard] or [autocard]Ornithopter[/autocard] can help you get some damage in, with this.

Knowledge is power!

31623: Mountain.author: TVsDB
31623: Mountain.text_parsed:
WotC rep 1: Well Rob, for our new block we are looking for some really intense mountain-scapes.
WotC rep 2: Yeah, stuff full of drama and really straightforward like Remote Farm.
Rep 1: And Web...
Rep 2: Great card, great card.
Rob Alexander rubs his chin, nodding in agreement. He pauses for a second.
Rob A: Got it!
The reps lean in closer
Rob: A giant.. hole!
Rep 2: A what?
Rep 1: No wait, you mean a volcano right? This is good.
Rep 2: Yeah, yeah, with like lava and stuff?
Rob A: No, not lava, WATER!
Rep 1: I'm sorry, is it a geyser?
Rob A: No, no, the water is going into the hole.
Rep 1 whispers to Rep 2: I think we've lost Rob.
Rep 2: Get Tony Szszudlo on the phone.

31738: Face of Fear.author: Ferlord
31738: Face of Fear.text_parsed:
I suppose you could use this to have some sort of discard engine in reanimation, but what's wrong with Putrid Imp? While I'm at it, I'll make a pros/cons chart between these two:

Face of Fear:

PRO
- Power and Toughness are better
- Offensively, Fear is better than Flying

CON
- Lower Rarity
- CMC is cheaper
- Discarding is free
- Defensively, Flying is better than Fear
- Has Threshold
- Is a Zombie Imp, a better creature type than Horror

Do I need to go any further? This is a... 'putrid' card (HAHAHAHA GET IT?!)

31738: Face of Fear.author: NARFNra
31738: Face of Fear.text_parsed:
Face of Fear, we meet again. You tend to bum around in the worst cards in the game area, along with your buddies Bog Hoodlums, Aven Trooper, and the king of the bottom, Razor Boomerang.

Honestly, I rated you a 1 rather than a .5, because he's not so terrible he can't block weenies. He won't block anything useful by the time you play him, and his evasion is less likely to be effective than winning the game through Game of Chance without Krark's Thumb, but at least you can be a discard outlet, even if there are oh so many better choices.

So I'll give you a 1. Because you're still terrible.

Why not use Tormod's Crypt?

Tormod's Crypt has to be in play, so your opponents can play around it. A Mudhole in response to their Crucible of Worlds has a massive suprise factor.

Furthermore, having a Mudhole resolved against you is the surest way to be put on permanent life tilt. Even if your opponent wins the match, they will most likely spiral into depression and commit suicide in the next few years.

31740: Mudhole.author: Salient
31740: Mudhole.text_parsed:
There really is a good reason to play this card in EDH: players who haven't seen it before will laugh until tears force their way out of their eyes.

The whole rest of the game (hell, the whole rest of the weekend) you'll hear people exclaiming, "Tarv??? TARV???"

Jokes about the utter mediocrity of Storm Crow are old by now. Hardly anyone has ever seen Mudhole. Everyone will get more sheer enjoyment out of this card than any other card they play. Nobody will remember who won the game that day; they'll just remember the asshat who played a @#$%ing Mudhole. And that's what EDH is all about!

31740: Mudhole.author: KablamoBoom
31740: Mudhole.text_parsed:
Wow, so many haters, I'm shocked this card doesn't have a higher rating.
I actually think this card is really useful, for several reasons. I run an Izzet storm/draw deck with a mana curve of almost solely 1, 2, and a few 6 cmc cards. Because the deck is purposefully designed to make you mill like crazy, I pack it with resets like Time Reversal and Elixir of Immortality, which will both help you draw more, and keep you from killing yourself. In a longer match I'll usually hit about thirty cards in the graveyard and start resetting by turn eight to ten, the problem at this point is cycling my mana ramp. When I hit the reset I wind up with all of the Terramorphic Expanses, Evolving Wilds and Scalding Tarns in my hand, when all of my mana is already in play. These cards are now the only thing preventing a win, because they keep me from drawing till a nuke like Grapeshot.

For three mana, Mudhole lets me reset only the important cards of the deck. Given, that's a lot of mana and it really isn't worth it if I'm playing right, but I see a lot more potential for this card in small decks that burn cards too quickly. If you're trying to set up a mana ramp in a deck with no curve and cmc of 1, this solves a lot of issues.

31761: Abandoned Outpost.author: DarthParallax
31761: Abandoned Outpost.text_parsed:
Hmm....This is a common. And I guess that was a pretty significant thing.

Odyssey Block? My guess is, that since Odyssey comes Directly after Invasion Block, that they wanted to give more Standard support to multicolored decks with the rotating of older Sets. Would that be Urza's Block too, or just Masques Block? And a Core Set? Not sure if that mattered or not. Still.

They also probably thought lands that could sacrifice themselves would help the Threshold mechanic, you know the way that Artifact Lands helped Affinity......I am not saying what *I* think, I'm saying what I think THEY thought XD

Honestly, I like the idea of the lands, but their execution turned out to be weak. Well, it's kind of good for common non-basic lands to be weak. It is only in the 15th and 20th Years, with Vivid Lands and Guildgates, that non-basic mana is ACTUALLY colorful and good at common. Wow.

Game's changed a lot. But these lands show a connection between two block themes, which shows R&D was beginning to get better at crafting Format environments.

31774: Thought Nibbler.author: Leshrac_Nightwalker
31774: Thought Nibbler.text_parsed:
ClockworkSwordfish and D|CK have the right of it. The card may seem like garbage now, but factoring in the set it was printed in, it makes a bit more sense. It was part of a cycle with Thought Eater and Thought Devourer - all three are agressively-costed blue creatures *with evasion* that reduce your hand size. The drawback was never attractive, but as Clockword pointed out, a clever player could make the resulting discard work for them.

On a flavour note - what a creepy-looking creature this is! It's interesting how this one is portrayed as a useful tool for wizards... when you compare this to the two bigger versions I mentioned above, it looks like the thought-eating cycle goes from useful to unwelcome, then from unwelcome to crippling!
31774: Thought Nibbler.text_posted:
ClockworkSwordfish and D|CK have the right of it.  The card may seem like garbage now, but factoring in the set it was printed in, it makes a bit more sense.  It was part of a cycle with [autocard]Thought Eater[/autocard] and [autocard]Thought Devourer[/autocard] - all three are agressively-costed blue creatures *with evasion* that reduce your hand size.  The drawback was never attractive, but as Clockword pointed out, a clever player could make the resulting discard work for them.  

On a flavour note - what a creepy-looking creature this is!  It's interesting how this one is portrayed as a useful tool for wizards... when you compare this to the two bigger versions I mentioned above, it looks like the thought-eating cycle goes from useful to unwelcome, then from unwelcome to crippling!

31778: Last Rites.author: achilleselbow
31778: Last Rites.text_parsed:
Play it in a reanimator deck, a madness deck, or use a lot of cards with Flashback. All of the above options are plentiful in Odyssey block. Yes, you lose one card in terms of card advantage, but you can discard your lands and most useless cards, and watching your opponent's face as you pick off his best cards is a real treat. "Hmm...I'll take this Broodmate Dragon and this Garruk... and what's this, a Blightning? Well, we wouldn't want to get hit by that, now would we?"

Anyway, turn 1 forest and llanowar elf or whatever, turn 2 swamp, cast last rites, discard a Fungal Shambler and some flashback cards, wreck your opponent's hand making sure to grab any removal and anything that he could cast in the next couple of turns, turn 3 play any land, Zombify the Shambler, and proceed to gain back the slight bit of card advantage you've lost.

31779: Words of Wisdom.author: Nate_Prawdzik
31779: Words of Wisdom.text_parsed:
You can get card advantage with this card, but it's not reliable. Going first, if they don't make a play by turn 2, then at end of turn you play this and draw 2. They draw 1 and discard (unless they have an instant).

Another way to get card advantage is once they have no more hand, at which point you need something like Liliana Vess, or any other reusable discard. Simply draw two and give them one, then take their one away (as long as it's not an instant they can play, that is).

Lastly, if you draw two cards and your cards are better, you can get card advantage as a result of holding two spells to their one. For example, let's say it's their end of turn and you both have empty hands except for this card you happen to be holding (which you play). You draw a Counterspell plus a card like Wrath of God or Stroke of Genius, and for the sake of argument, assume they draw a good card as well. Simply Wrath the board (or Stroke up or whatever) for big card advantage, and even assuming they didn't draw a dud, you will have your remaining counter in hand to stop whatever you gave them, thus putting you ahead on card advantage. Basically, the better your deck compared to the opponent, the better of a deal this becomes.

31791: Psionic Gift.author: DarthKithkin
31791: Psionic Gift.text_parsed: can you enchant an opponents creature with this and use it to ping itself or others?
31791: Psionic Gift.text_posted: can you enchant an opponents creature with this and use it to ping itself or others?

31791: Psionic Gift.author: Ichorix
31791: Psionic Gift.text_parsed:
@DarkKithkin:

No. Notice it says "Enchanted creature has..." The creature basically gains a pinging ability, and only a creature's controller can activate abilities on creatures he or she controls unless explicitly stated otherwise (Feral Hydra, for example). You control the aura, not the creature. Now, if it said "tap this card and the creature it enchants" then it would work that way. But as it is, no.
31791: Psionic Gift.text_posted:
@DarkKithkin:

No. Notice it says "Enchanted creature has..." The creature basically gains a pinging ability, and only a creature's controller can activate abilities on creatures he or she controls unless explicitly stated otherwise ([autocard]Feral Hydra[/autocard], for example). You control the aura, not the creature. Now, if it said "tap this card and the creature it enchants" then it would work that way. But as it is, no.

In case you're looking for the same thing in red, try Power of Fire. (It could be considered a planeshifted version.)

In that case, you probably want to run Fire Whip instead, which can also be sacrificed for 1 damage. It can only be cast on your creatures, but it's not like you were planning on making one of your opponent's creature a pinger anyways.

31793: Sarcatog.author: blurrymadness
31793: Sarcatog.text_parsed:
3/5 seems about right. He can still hit for a bunch of damage, but the artifact bit is clunky and R/B aren't typically who build around artifacts. Further most Red artifact cards either blow it up for damage or use it in the graveyard for damage/pump; meaning competing abilities.

This is a build around card that doesn't fit into a non-build around deck very well. The grave ability does make him a potential finisher however, so he might be fun to try out in long casual matches.

31795: Tremble.author: Mode
31795: Tremble.text_parsed:
Use with Flagstones of Trokair, Gods' Eye, Gate to the Reikai, or even Dakmor Salvage.

Raze is usually preferable though - it costs less and you even get to choose the land.
Unless your opponent's land are all either consecrated, fortified with or even made of Darksteel. Which is very unlikely.

And even if Raze gets countered it ain't that bad if you still just get to search a Plains. (The 1/1 spirit or the ability to Dredge might not be always that preferable to your land, but that likely won't make you worry as often as paying more mana or not being able to choose their Rishadan Port, Mishra's Factory or Contested Cliffs.)

31795: Tremble.author: Salient
31795: Tremble.text_parsed:
This is truly awful in multiplayer.

Pro: You can destroy ten lands for the price of one, in a large enough game. That makes Tremble the most efficient land destruction card ever printed in the history of (multiplayer) magic.

Con: You effectively receive an emblem with "Creatures opponents control attack you each turn if able. Spells opponents control target you if their effect is nasty. Any number of players may decide to not invite you to lunch at end of game."

31798: Decimate.author: Talcos
31798: Decimate.text_parsed:
This card is perfect for EDH. Invariably, in a game with multiple opponents, you will have an artifact, creature, enchantment, and land that needs to be destroyed. Decimate can take care of all of them at the same time, and for only four mana.

Besides, if you can't make the count (say you're lacking an enchantment), you can always destroy something of your own that you don't mind losing. For instance, would you give up a token creature to get rid of an enchantment, artifact, and land? It still seems like a very good deal to me.

If they ever change the rules in magic, making cards like this and Hex legal to cast even if there isnt the required legal targets on the field.

It should be that way, if you cast hex and they sac all but 1 creature in response, the spell doesnt fizzle that creature still gets nuked. But if there is only 5 legal targets for Hex you cannot cast it at all.

Same with this thing, if you can hit a creature, artfiact, and a land, you cannot cast it at all because you need to have all 4 targeted when you cast. But if they sac one or 2 or even 3 things in response, then the spell will go off just fine.

If they made the needed change then this would be allot better.

31799: Iridescent Angel.author: The_Murderauder
31799: Iridescent Angel.text_parsed:
@smilie23: A creature with protection from a color can't be targeted, dealt damage, enchanted, or blocked by anything of that color (The same is true for any other form of protection, like "protection from goblins" or "protection from artifacts"). So while your Wrath and Disk examples are correct, Hurricane would be ineffective.

@BrimandVormay:
Something that is multicolored (gold or hybrid) is considered any and all of the colors that it is, at all times, for all purposes relating to color. Color is color. Now, for contrast, Guardian of the Guildpact has exactly the ability you described.

Still a very nice card. It's in the goldilock zone and you can pick it up for a buck.

4/5

~Zuty

31802: Dreamwinder.author: DarthParallax
31802: Dreamwinder.text_parsed:
ooohh!!!! what an intriguing ability! of course the execution sucks, but this card makes me want to think of ways to turn it into something good:

obviously the first step is to bump it up to rare- because we're going to be making a somewhat strange card in a lot of ways, and the place for strange cards that have worth-playing potential but might flop unless you get your deck right seems to be 'rare' right now, uncommons having taken 'reliable small effects' place and mythics taking 'this is a good card. it wins the game' place. So a really proper-done sacc-ing Serpent is going to be a rare because it will need to be powerful but not too consistent and definitely not small.

The second thing you do, after you say 'let's make it a RARE serpent', is you start looking at the Power, Toughness, and CMC numbers with new eyes. Rares have quite a different budge than commons for this area, even in blue. I think a modern Rare serpent could argue that 2UU should get him a size of 5/6 of 6/5. Pretty beefy, in other words, and really really beefy for 4 mana in blue.

That's is the main thing 'Islandhome' has always been missing in the first place: it's used as a drawback for flavor reasons, and then none of it's creatures are above the mana-power curve. that's wrong. drawback creatures should make up for it somewhere else, and high power numbers is the place to do it.

Lastly, that 'until end of turn' text is horridly awful. Even if my creature was a 5/5 for 1UU and nothing else, I wouldn't sac a land just to let him attack. Probably. But I like the idea of saccing a land to do something-

How about:
New and Improved Serpent 2UU
Rare
Islandhome
Sac a land: Put a flood counter on each land. Those lands are Islands as long as you control New and Improved Serpent. When New and Improved Serpent leaves the battlefield, remove all flood counters from lands.
6/5

There. I don't know if this is all that exciting a card, but by Serpent Standards, it's great: you sac a land to color-hose your opponent while at the same time letting your Serpent attack until it's dead or until your opponent finds some way to fix the flood. It's a 6/5 for 4 mana which is a lot but rares are allowed to do that. It's an early drop card though for Blue, so your opponent will probably play more lands of the colors they need. It's not going to horribly ruin your day- it will just ask you to come up with an answer quickly, but that answer should be easy to find.

Maybe a different card can be made in White called 'Purify Land' or something, that removes all counters from lands? In a Core Set with Obsidian Fireheart and something black that does something or other? :)

I've always wanted there to be a Serpent that was really really cool and worth playing, because the mechanics of Serpents are fundamentally interesting from a strategy perspective- if Wizards would just be willing to push the P/T numbers more on them so that they'd be worth the risks, Serpents would have a lot of respect I think...

31808: Infected Vermin.author: Equinox523
31808: Infected Vermin.text_parsed:
Costly activation compared to similar effects (Gangrenous Zombies comes to mind), but also potentially a board wipe with Basilisk Collar. Heck, you even get life back.

Other fun stuff you can do with this:

- Mask of Law and Grace granting it protection from its own ability, for repeated Pestilence. Also Crown of Awe to protect your other creatures, or Strength of Isolation if playing a Madness deck.

- Let it die to set up a Tragic Slip and other Morbid spells.

- Enchant with Spirit Mantle to protect it from its own abilities.

31809: Sadistic Hypnotist.author: ThatGuyYouHate
31809: Sadistic Hypnotist.text_parsed: With Nath as my general in EDH every tutor I draw basically says. "Find and play sadistic hypnotist, play nath for complete lock down and an army." Then the next tutor I draw says. " Go get asceticism or Kamahl and finish the poor bastard." Nath is the perfect embodiment of Black Green btw. Discarding and elves. and he even forces a discard to make sure he doesn't just sit there. The Sadistic Hypno and Nath combo also works well with Nullmage shepherd, geths grimiore, grave pact, phyrexian altar, and It That Betrays. Once you get that web out if your opponent keeps a card in hand they are going to be screwed over.

31815: Aven Fisher.author: Sumai4444
31815: Aven Fisher.text_parsed: No, I think the flavor text means that the defender and hunter for the village will one day do battle for the village. and even if he falls, his spear will be used by another. So to follow the text, the creature should be a 1/2 flyer, that  has rule text comes into play with a Token equipment card that reads, Aven Spear, Equipped Creature gains +1/+0. Equip cost 1, automatically equips Aven Fisher when it comes into play. Or better yet, a equipment permanent named Aven Fisher Spear, that has the same ability, and when Aven Fisher comes into play, attach this spear for free, or if no legal targets, search your library for Aven Fisher Spear and attach to Aven Fisher. The ability to draw a card is a blue common throwback to make higher casting cost commons have flying and allow you to draw a card upon some sort of activation. In this case maybe the flavor text should have read, "Few have greater knowledge of tactics than those who use their hunting skills to defend their own, even after death, that knowledge remains for anyone wise enough to listen..." or something to that effect.

31818: Mad Dog.author: Tevish_Szat
31818: Mad Dog.text_parsed: Bears with drawbacks are usually bad, but you have to remember this little puppy is from Odyssey, where graveyards mattered.  In that set, being able to just sacrifice your early attacker for Threshold fodder when you no longer need it might be important.  Still, not a good card: there are plenty of ways to kill your own creatures without resorting to "Attack with me or I die" as a strategy.  And really, you're going to attack into overwhelming power if you want it dead anyway, and might get damage through if your opponent thinks you're up to something, so what's the point?

31818: Mad Dog.author: DarthParallax
31818: Mad Dog.text_parsed:
actually, I'm going to stand up for this card.


it's not powerful, it's weak, I'll grant.


but listen--

a) It's a Common.
b) Designing for Limited is in the first place a questionable thing to be doing,
c) And in the Second Place, hadn't been practiced very much at this point anyway.


This card has a mechanic that simply basically tries to push you to attack with it. I'd say it's honestly not much worse or better than Jackal Pup from a Design perspective, and from a Development perspective as a Common it's not supposed to be too good anyway, it's the Rares that sell packs and the Rares that are going to be the Bomb that wins you the game if you're looking for Bombs.

This pairs very nicely with Glory Seeker in a crude but effective White-Red Aggressive attacking deck.


If this were Uncommon or Rare, it would be more reasonable to want it to be more positive and not negative, but

d) Negative effects breed creative, awesome, broken decks that are a blast to discover.

e) If Commons were allowed to be Worse, then Rares and Mythics wouldn't have to be Broken to be Playable.

f) Just Think of it as a Red Bears.

31821: Aboshan, Cephalid Emperor.author: Travis_86
31821: Aboshan, Cephalid Emperor.text_parsed:
Brutal Emperor of the Cephalids. Controlled a secret network of flooded tunnels throughout Otaria. His hatred of "drylanders" included the desire to conquer Otaria, and to this end he maintained a tenuous political alliance with the Cabal. When Kirtar lost control of the Mirari and died, Cephalid agents retrieved the orb and brought it to Aboshan's treasury. There, Laquatus tried to steal it, but the Emperor lost control of its power and sank most of Northern Otaria beneath the ocean (the Mirari's literal interpretation of his desires). Aboshan was killed, and the Mirari fell into the hands of Braids, the Cabal's liaison to the Empire, who returned it to the Cabal Patriarch. After Aboshan's death, Laquatus tried and failed to conquer the remains of his Empire.

Deluge
Aboshan's Desire
