31821: Aboshan, Cephalid Emperor.author: Mode
31821: Aboshan, Cephalid Emperor.text_parsed:
(Creature type rant)

I wonder if Aboshan's ability is the reason why they wouldn't just drop the type Cephalid for Octopus.
When he was printed, there was only one Octopus in existance - and a forgettable one at that.
So i wonder what kept them from making them Octopuses in the first place.

Surprisingly, the Grad Creature Type Update didn't change that.
By now we only got one more (although granted, a very notable one).

This is about the only humanoid, animal-based species in existance that does not simply use its species' type.

Seriously, the examples are endless and span almost every major classification imaginable:
- Aven: Birds. First showed up at the same time as Cephalids, yet didn't get a seperate race either. Often Soldiers.
- Nantuko: Insects. Again, same as with our avian Aven. Usually Shamans.
- Anurids: Same again. Originally Beasts, now more fittingly Frog Beasts.
- Loxodon: Elephants. Thick-skinned Soldiers and Clerics from Mirrodin.
- Leonin: Cats. More white Soldiers and Clerics from Mirrodin, this time felines.
- Nezumi: Rats. Relentless Ninja and Samurai rodents from Kamigawa.
- Kitsune: Foxes. Mythic canines from Kamigawa.
- Orochi: Snakes. The most extreme example, sharing less traits with its actual species than Cephalids.

The only other exception i can think of are:
1. The infamous Homarids. They first showed up in Fallen Empires, so them having a seperate type comes as little surprise. Wizards might simply kept that type for fun because of its special status, considering the infamy it gathered that even resulted in a whole new type in Unglued that's based on them: Clamfolk.
2. Viashino: Although their first major appearance was in Urza Block, they first showed up in Visions.
Which is another old set that still cared very little about creating overly specific creature types.
Oh, wait. Actually Viashino Warrior is even older, which first showed up in Mirage, the expansion right before Visions. So, err... if anything, this makes my point even more obvious, doesn't it?
I bet if this race would have first shown up in Ravnica Block (maybe even Urza Block), they would've just been Lizards (or Dragon Lizards, see my comment here for details).

Obviously i'm not the one to decide that stuff, but it just seems logical to either give all or none of these animal-based humanoids a unique type.

TL;DR: Since (to the enjoyment of every tribal fanatic) about 90% of humanoid animal species went for the animal's type, i'd really like a type change for those who did not.

31825: Psychatog.author: Equinox523
31825: Psychatog.text_parsed:
Poor, poor Shadowmage Infiltrator. It probably would have been UB's main 3-drop if it hadn't been for this guy...

A highly versatile creature and the perfect finisher for its colors. The fact that it could eat both cards in the graveyard or in hand meant that it could do evil, evil things if allowed to go unblocked. The possibility that Wonder could be in hand made the threat of lethal damage even more viable. Cheap evasion-granting effects like Shadow Rift (with cantrip, no less) can simultaneously force it through the red zone, and give it more ammo to munch on.

One of the most dangerous creatures in Magic history.

31825: Psychatog.author: DarthParallax
31825: Psychatog.text_parsed:
Psychatog's Deck was nothing at all like the Cat-Blasph-trophemy that was Urza's Block. Not a single card that got banned from Urza's Block would have been ok, in ANY context imaginable while still keeping the game at all recognizable as "Magic: the Gathering".

Psychatog was strangely fortunate to be sure, and a lot of players were strangely unfortunate because of that, but individually, a great many of the Psychatog Decks' cards can have fairer homes found for them.

31825: Psychatog.author: Aquillion
31825: Psychatog.text_parsed:
@TheWrathofShane: The issue is that people would run it with Upheaval, so your removal (unless it only costs one mana) won't do you any good. All they have to do is trade off one-for-one counters or removal until they have eight lands out (filling their graveyard in the process), then tap all lands, Upheaval, play one land again, and play their tog. The next turn, unless you have a one-mana answer, they discard eight cards, exile their entire graveyard, and attack you for game. It doesn't matter that the boost only lasts one turn when it can get twenty power in an empty field.

It's both ridiculously effective and unbelievably boring to play against.

Even without that combo, this card is very good simply for the ability to discard at will -- all sorts of decks can benefit from that, especially if you're using Madness or reanimate.

31826: Druid's Call.text_posted: If I have a 2/2 that is attacked by a 6/6 and blocks it with this enchantment on it, do 6 squirrels come into play? Or perhaps when an instant does 6 damage to it? 31826: Druid's Call.text_posted: In all of those cases it would be 6 squirrels or life. All 6 damage is being dealt to your creature, even if it is excess; the only time 2 would be dealt is by a 6/6 with trample.

31826: Druid's Call.author: UnluckyDevil
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
I believe this is actually how it would work.

It would be six life, but only 1 squirrel. The card says "Whenever enchanted creature is dealt damage..."

http://www.wizards.com/magic/rules/EN_Magic_Basic_Rulebook_20090710.pdf

Page 16 Section d. Combat damage step.

"Once players decide how the creatures they control will deal their combat damage, the damage is all dealt at the same time."

This means only one squirrel is produced because damage is only dealt once.
31826: Druid's Call.text_posted:
I believe this is actually how it would work.

It would be six life, but only 1 squirrel. The card says "Whenever enchanted creature is [u]dealt[/u] damage..."

http://www.wizards.com/magic/rules/EN_Magic_Basic_Rulebook_20090710.pdf

Page 16 Section d. Combat damage step.

"Once players decide how the creatures they control will deal their combat damage, [u]the damage is all dealt at the same time[/u]."

This means only one squirrel is produced because damage is only dealt once.

31826: Druid's Call.author: CeremonialBathory
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed: @UnluckyDevil: You mean 2 tokens. The enchantment says "that many" referring to the damage, doesn't it? Yes, damage hits all at once - but a 2/2 creature will take up to 2 damage normally. UNLESS the 6/6 has something that allows it to assign more damage than the creature's toughness, like Lifelink, then only two tokens are generated. If it's a Lifelink 6/6, then it can deal 6 damage to the 2/2, allowing its controller to gain 6 life and the person with this enchantment to get 6 squirrel tokens.
31826: Druid's Call.text_posted: @UnluckyDevil: You mean 2 tokens. The enchantment says "that many" referring to the damage, doesn't it? 31826: Druid's Call.author: ScissorsLizard
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
I think Sooku is right. Unless the attacking creature has trample, it will deal the full 6 damage to the enchanted creature.

UnluckyDevil is correct in his assertion that all combat is dealt at one time, but he misread the card. The card says to put that many tokens into play, meaning a number of tokens equal to the damage. So the enchanted creature takes 6, and 6 tokens come into play. The same works with lifelink- the full 6 damage is dealt, even if only 2 is required to kill the creature, so you gain 6 life.

31826: Druid's Call.author: Aburaishi
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
Guys, I think the thing UnluckyDevil was confused about wasn't whether the creature would be dealt 6 or 2 damage, but whether the amount of squirrel tokens obtained was dependent on how many times damage was dealt or how much damage was dealt.

UnluckyDevil, the card says "its controller puts that many 1/1 green Squirrel creature tokens into play" whenever damage is dealt to the creature; so it checks to see if damage was dealt, then checks to see how much damage was dealt. Otherwise it would read "Every time enchanted creature is dealt damage, its controller may put a 1/1 green Squirrel creature token into play".
31826: Druid's Call.text_posted:
Guys, I think the thing UnluckyDevil was confused about wasn't whether the creature would be dealt 6 or 2 damage, but whether the amount of squirrel tokens obtained was dependent on how many [i]times[/i] damage was dealt or how [i]much[/i] damage was dealt.

UnluckyDevil, the card says "its controller puts [i]that many[/i] 1/1 green Squirrel creature tokens into play" whenever damage is dealt to the creature; so it checks to see if damage was dealt, then checks to see how much damage was dealt. Otherwise it would read "Every time enchanted creature is dealt damage, its controller may put a 1/1 green Squirrel creature token into play".

31826: Druid's Call.author: endersblade
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
Wow...I'm so glad I don't play with most of you people.

If you put this on a 1/1, and blocked an infinite/infinite, non-tramply creature, you'd get infinite tokens. It doesn't matter if the 1/1 only needs one damage to kill it; if the attacker doesn't have trample or any other type of evasion, ALL the damage is dealt to the 1/1, not just 'lethal' damage.

Back during odyssey, I used to run one killer squirrel deck. This card was included. I recently updated it with Swarmyard for even more shenanigans. Toss this on a Krosan Beast + Lure and make a truckload of squirrels.

31826: Druid's Call.author: DarthParallax
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
I'm not yet saying there is, but if anyone knows of a way to enchant Progenitus with anything, THIS is what I would want to enchant him with the most. :3

Just casting the enchantment is, obviously, not enough, but 'attach' is word that could be used in some little-known Johnny-tastic card that would permit an enchantment to land on Progenitus, if the word 'target' does not appear. I'm going to do more research then come back and edit this comment. :D

EDIT: Bingo. >:D While Aura Finesse, Aura Graft, and pretty much probably all the White and Blue Magic you can think of seem to be well aware that someone could think of doing something nasty like Enchant creatures Not Meant to Be Enchanted, and so were worded carefully to close the possibility, Ice Age is a set made before the Johnny Psychographic started doing REALLY improper things with cardboard, so the Rules Texts were not worded as carefully back then. :) Therefore, may I present the Best Combo Ever:

Druid's Call. Mob of Squirrels. Progenitus. Crown of Ages.

31826: Druid's Call.author: Gandlodder
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
@Darth_Parallax:
While I applaud the effort you put into your combo, I have to point out the unfortunate reason why it does not work. If Progenitus had something like shroud or hexproof, then your method would work. Protection, however, also prevents enchantments from sticking to it. For example, if you used an Eight-and-a-Half-Tails to give a pacified creature protection from white, the pacifism would fall off. For the same reason, cheating any enchantment onto Progenitus will simply result in the enchantment falling off into the graveyard. Also, a flipped Kitsune Mystic would do the job of Crown of the Ages, and from a set much newer than Ice Age.
31826: Druid's Call.text_posted:
@Darth_Parallax:

For example, if you used an [autocard]Eight-and-a-Half-Tails[/autocard] to give a [autocard multiverseid="370812"]pacified[/autocard] creature protection from white, the pacifism would fall off. 31826: Druid's Call.author: Bbone37
31826: Druid's Call.text_parsed:
When thinking about protection (at least in the realm of MTG), remeber "DEBT", boys and girls:

DAMAGE
ENCHANTING
BLOCKING
TARGETING

So like Gandlodder said, Progen couldnt be enchanted. He has protection from err'thang... Your idea works for shroud and such, Darth, but not protection

EDIT: Just though of something else crucial; even IF you could get this to stick to Progen, he has protection from everything, therefor nothing can damage him, thus no tokens would be made....

If you're playing an atog deck, you sort of feel like you should be playing their lord, which is one of the worst creatures ever, so he leads to moral dilemmas as well as lost games. An experiment: build a deck that includes Atogatog, but not Dragon Gate. I guarantee you that the deck will be better if you replace the Atogatog with a Sliver Queen, even if the deck contains zero other Slivers and many Atogs. Even if the deck contains Plague Sliver.

31834: Atogatog.author: Hungerstriker
31834: Atogatog.text_parsed:
HAVE NONE OF YOU POOR SOULS EVER BEEN TOLD ABOUT COMMANDER???

Seriously, not a single comment even addresses his potential as a commander. Atogatog is a hilarious and deceptively powerful general for a wacky five-color combo-control deck. You can smash in and score a commander kill, sure, aided by cards like Artful Dodge and Rancor, but the super cool way to win is to wait until your opponent is ending his turn and spring your combo: Thaumatog eats all your lands, Psychatog eats your hand, and Atogatog promptly gobbles up everything remaining, including itself. You win at upkeep with Barren Glory.

31839: Animal Boneyard.author: DacenOctavio
31839: Animal Boneyard.text_parsed:
It's rated low because:

A) It's an aura. Which means you go down a card when you play this unless you're an enchantress deck; that's one less card in your hand that could have been something. . . else. This card isn't powerful to justify giving a card slot in constructed unless for some reason you really need to sacrifice creatures and for some reason conventional sac outlets like Claws of Gix just aren't cutting it for you.

B) High Market is only $5 USD to avoid the conundrums above and still have a decent land. Miren, the Moaning Well costs even less.

31852: Upheaval.author: zk3
31852: Upheaval.text_parsed:
Back when this was standard, resolving it usually resulted in a win - people equated it to Yawgmoth's Will in terms of what it did in the environment. It's slower than will, but standard is slower than vintage. Neither are game-winning on their own, but TPS or UB tog are well-built decks that integrate these trump cards.
When this resolves, all the spells (permanents) you played for the entire game come back for grand finale.

31852: Upheaval.author: EvilCowKing
31852: Upheaval.text_parsed:
"Instant Win" mid-game in a Blue / Black Deck:

1. Don't play your land for the turn.
2. Cast Upheaval.
3. Play a Swamp, tap, Dark Ritual -> Megrim / Liliana's Caress.

If your opponent has 20 life, making them discard 10 cards (shouldn't be difficult at all by that point in the the game) will win you the game as soon as their clean up step comes. Just hope they're not playing W, or else it's Plains, tap, Demystify for you! xD

31852: Upheaval.author: Antsache
31852: Upheaval.text_parsed: Just because I don't see many people talking about it: whatever its uses were back in its standard days, it takes on a whole new kind of power in today's cube formats. If you can early pick Upheaval, the rest of your draft is focused on picking up as many mana rocks and decent counterspells as you can get. Going off is easy: float all your mana, Upheaval, replay as many of your ramp artifacts as possible, tap them (for the second time that turn), and keep playing stuff. Your opponent is set back to turn one, but you're often looking at 6+ mana available on your next turn.

31853: Traveling Plague.author: majinara
31853: Traveling Plague.text_parsed:
- kills creatures with shroud (when it returns to play, since it then doesnt target)
- kills indestructible creatures
- kills creatures with regeneration

Especially fun in multiplayer games, since there are enough creatures are around, and the card works much faster each turn.

And it's fun as well if you have creatures in play, that other people don't want to die, such as Goblin Gardener or Rukh Egh.

31853: Traveling Plague.author: Mode
31853: Traveling Plague.text_parsed:
majinara is right, but for five mana this is too slow actually. i think it should either immediatly kill the creature at the beginning of its controller's upkeep instead (losing the latter two advantages from P/T shrinking), or have a lower mana cost instead.
i actually think this could find good use if it just was cheaper...

but you have to wait an upkeep for each point of toughness and will afterwards even get the plague, that's not much for 5 mana...
of course you can only play creatures with p.i.g. effects to reduce the drawback, but i think the best use for this card should be in control decks that don't run any creatures at all.

31854: New Frontiers.author: CallmeMerry
31854: New Frontiers.text_parsed:
With SoM now, I have a deck based around Tunnel Ignus + Invader Parasite. With one of each out, my opponent can only search for one card. In a monodeck, that is a guaranteed 2 damage. Every land after that costs 5 life to my opponent. Certainly not the most powerful combo, but it is fun. Although I do have to admit that it becomes significantly less powerful against multicolored decks (although it is still 3 life every land after the first thanks to the Ignus).

Other than that, it is just a bunch of landfall effects that really make this card shine. Lotus Cobra pretty much negates the cost of this spell so you can throw something else out there, Avenger of Zendikar is....yeah, overrun your opponents with Rampaging Baloths. The list goes on (Roil Elemental is my favorite though).

31867: Hint of Insanity.author: Equinox523
31867: Hint of Insanity.text_parsed:
Some minor fixes could have made this at least a playable card - as it is, there is a real possibility of spending 3 mana on NOTHING. Making this a more powerful Coercion would have at least rendered it more playable.

Fixed Hint of Insanity:
Target player reveals his or her hand. You choose a card from it. That player discards that card, and then discards all cards with the same name as that card.

Sure, you lose some of the spirit of the card, but it at least guarantees you never pay 3 mana for nothing. And seeing that Odyssey was a graveyard set, you could also use it on yourself to meet threshold or activate flashback, etc. While not amazing, it'd at least be playable.

31868: Chamber of Manipulation.author: Ladon---
31868: Chamber of Manipulation.text_parsed:
I think everyone here is missing something very important.

"Until the end of turn" makes effects end at the beginning of the next end step. If you activate this during your opponent's end step, you gain control of the creature for the duration of your coming turn, it untaps if tapped, and does not have summoning sickness in response to changing owners.

Let me know if I'm missing something here, but it certainly seems that a repeatable, free Act of Treason every turn is something that would be way overpowered.

EDIT: @Kryptnyt
Thanks for clearing that up :D I guess all one would really need is to steal creatures with Haste built in!

31868: Chamber of Manipulation.author: ScissorsLizard
31868: Chamber of Manipulation.text_parsed:
@Ladon: As a point of clarification, you have the right idea, but this card has the wrong text. If it had read "At the beginning of the next end step", you could activate it during the end step so it would carry over to the next turn.

Something else to remember when you're looking at this card- not only does the creature not gain haste, it also doesn't untap. So if you're using it to gain control of tapped, attacking creatures, you won't be able to block with them. Best use: gain control of their biggest creature each turn before they attack. That should dissuade them from attacking at all.

This card also combos well with madness, and Barrin, Master Wizard.

31870: Cephalid Retainer.author: jsttu
31870: Cephalid Retainer.text_parsed: I don't really like this in a control deck because a smart player will see if you tap out to tap his creatures. If you do you don't have a counterspell and can't bluff, and if you don't tap them you are obviously holding on to something and he should just use what wasn't tapped to smash your face in. A savvy opponent turns this into a lose-lose situation. I suppose that when you don't have to tap out it would be better, but that isn't the most efficient, even if blue is the color of instants.

31872: Karmic Justice.author: sarroth
31872: Karmic Justice.text_parsed: Unfortunately, this won't trigger off of losing an aura when a creature is targeted and destroyed, as the aura is put into the graveyard by a state-based-action, and is not technically destroyed by the effect which destroyed the creature it was attached to and caused that state-based-action to put it into the graveyard. If it did, my Voltron deck would be even happier to have this. As is, it is still great protection for running enchantment-based removal such as Arrest and Oblivion Ring (even more unfortunate, you won't be able to target what you exiled with O-Ring with Karmic Justice...). Further, this is fantastic protection when you have a Greater Auramancy + Sterling Grove shield on the board, Karmic Justice protects against your opponents answering with a Planar Cleansing. A reprint would be nice. Perhaps a future Commander set will have an enchantment theme and could include this in its list.

33604: Shadowmage Infiltrator.author: Moleland
33604: Shadowmage Infiltrator.text_parsed:
Fear doesn't = intimidate

Fear = Can only be blocked by black or artifact creatures

Intimidate = can only be blocked by same colour creatures or artifact creatures

Mostly, Fear is on black creatures so they are interchangerable. However, you can enchant creatures with fear it is useful. Also, If all creatures become a single colour (IE: not black) A creature with fear is unblockable, whereas in the same senario, a creature with intimidate is kinda hosed
